title: Auto-Owners Insurance Company v. Horne
description: In this declaratory judgment action, minor child was not a resident relative of her father and stepmother's household and, thus, was not a Class I insured entitled to stack underinsured motorist's benefits.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        Auto-Owners Insurance Company, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Shirley Maxine Horne, Crystal Horne, and Michael Horne, Appellants.
      
    
  



Appeal From Saluda County
  L. Lee Plumblee, Special Referee

Opinion No. 3674
  Heard June 11, 2003 â€“ Filed September 15, 2003

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Jon E. Newlon and John R. McCravy, III, both of Greenwood, for Appellants.
        James P. Walsh, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CONNOR, J.:Â  In this declaratory judgment 
  action, the special referee found Crystal Horne was not a Class I insured entitling 
  her to stack underinsured motorist benefits under Shirley Maxine Horneâ€™s automobile 
  insurance policy.Â  Crystal, Shirley Maxine, and Michael Horne appeal, arguing 
  the referee erred in finding: (1) Crystal was not a resident relative of Shirley 
  Maxine Horne and Michael Horneâ€™s household, and (2) Crystal was not herself 
  a named insured on the policy.Â Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Crystal Horneâ€™s parents divorced on July 22, 1988.Â  The final 
  divorce decree, entered in Saluda County, ordered that Crystalâ€™s mother, Dianne 
  Williams (Williams), â€œbe granted the permanent care, custody and control of 
  the partiesâ€™ minor childrenâ€ and that Michael Horne (Mr. Horne) â€œbe granted 
  the right to reasonable periods of visitation with the partiesâ€™ minor children.â€Â  
  After the divorce, Crystalâ€™s mother remarried and remained living in Saluda 
  until moving to Conway in 1992.Â  Crystal, however, stayed with her father in 
  the Greenwood/Saluda area for approximately three months before moving to Horry 
  County to live with her mother and younger sister.Â  Before she moved to Horry 
  County, Crystal had lived with Williams in Saluda and had stayed with her father 
  during the summer months and every other weekend during the school year. 
On March 9, 1997, Crystal sustained personal injuries from 
  an automobile wreck in Horry County while operating a 1987 Chevrolet Camaro.Â  
  The Camaro was insured under an automobile policy issued by Auto-Owners Insurance 
  Company (Auto-Owners) to Shirley Maxine Horne (Mrs. Horne) as the named insured.Â  
  Mrs. Horne is Michael Horneâ€™s wife and Crystalâ€™s stepmother.Â  Mr. Horne owned 
  the Camaro.Â  At the time of the accident, Crystal was seventeen years old and 
  her driverâ€™s license listed an address in Conway.Â  Crystal stated the address 
  on the driverâ€™s license is where she was living with her mother at the time 
  of the accident. [1]  
 From 1992 until the date of the accident, Crystal continued to live with Williams 
  in the Conway area and visited her father in Saluda during the summers, holidays, 
  and occasional weekends during the school year. Â Crystal would usually 
  spend the whole summer with her father in Saluda.Â  However, the summer prior 
  to the accident Crystal stayed in Saluda for only a few days during the summer.Â  
  During Crystalâ€™s trips to Saluda, she would also visit and stay with her grandmothers 
  and aunts, who lived in the area.Â  
Following the accident, Crystal recovered the limits against the liability 
  insurance carrier for the at-fault driver and then made a claim to Auto-Owners 
  for underinsured motorist (UIM) benefits.Â  Auto-Owners paid Crystal the primary 
  UIM coverage on the vehicle involved in the wreck. 
  [2] Crystal then submitted a claim to Auto-Owners seeking to recover additional 
  UIM benefits by stacking coverages of other vehicles insured under Mrs. Horneâ€™s 
  policy.Â  
Auto-Owners filed this declaratory judgment action 
  seeking to determine Crystalâ€™s eligibility for stacking UIM benefits under the 
  policy.Â  Pursuant to Rule 53(b), SCRCP, the parties consented to have the matter 
  heard by a special referee, with appeal from the refereeâ€™s final judgment to 
  be made directly to this Court.Â  The referee found Crystal was not entitled 
  to stack UIM benefits because she was not a named insured on the Auto-Owners 
  policy and did not reside in the named insuredâ€™s household at the time of the 
  accident.Â  The Hornes appeal. [3] 
STANDARD OF REVIEW  
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, 
  but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland 
  County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  â€œAn issue essentially 
  one at law will not be transformed into one in equity simply because declaratory 
  relief is sought.â€Â  Id.
The issue here involves whether Crystal can stack underinsured 
  motorist coverage available under an insurance policy.Â  â€œAn action to determine 
  coverage under an insurance policy is an action at law.â€Â  South Carolina 
  Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 525, 528-29, 544 S.E.2d 848, 
  849 (Ct. App. 2001); see Richardson v. South Carolina Farm Bureau 
  Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 233, 519 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating an 
  action seeking a declaration of whether coverage under uninsured motorist policies 
  could be stacked is an action at law); see also State Auto Prop. & 
  Cas. Ins. Co. v. Gibbs, 314 S.C. 345, 444 S.E.2d 504 (1994) (stating an 
  action to declare excess insurance coverage is an action at law).Â  

  In a non-jury action at law, the judgeâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed 
    on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support.Â  Rickborn v. Liberty 
    Life Ins. Co., 321 S.C. 291, 468 S.E.2d 292 (1996).Â  The trial courtâ€™s 
    findings of fact have the same force and effect as a jury verdict unless it 
    committed some error of law leading to an erroneous conclusion or unless the 
    evidence is reasonably susceptible of the opposite conclusion only.Â  Noisette 
    v. Ismail, 299 S.C. 243, 384 S.E.2d 310 (Ct. App. 1989), revâ€™d on other 
    grounds, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991).Â  We must affirm the trial 
    court if there is any evidence that reasonably supports its decision.Â  Id.Â  
    In reviewing the findings, we must view the evidence and all its reasonable 
    inferences in the light least favorable to the losing party below.Â  Id.

Hiott v. Guar. Natâ€™l Ins. Co., 329 S.C. 522, 
  528-29, 496 S.E.2d 417, 421 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION  
 The Hornes argue the evidence established that Crystal resided with her father 
  for part of the year and the special referee thus erred in finding as a matter 
  of law that Crystal was not a resident relative of her fatherâ€™s household for 
  stacking purposes.Â  Â Â 
â€œStacking is the insuredâ€™s recovery of damages 
  under more than one policy until the insured satisfies all of his damages or 
  exhausts the limits of all available policies.â€Â  Contâ€™l Ins. Co. v. Shives, 
  328 S.C. 470, 473, 492 S.E.2d 808, 810 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œIn determining whether 
  an insured can stack, insureds are divided into two classes:Â  Class I and Class 
  II.Â  Only Class I insureds can stack.â€Â  State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. 
  James, 337 S.C. 86, 94, 522 S.E.2d 345, 349 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Previous cases 
  have stated section 38-77-160 of the South Carolina Code of Laws [4]  is the statute controlling the right to stack 
  and that under this section â€œa Class I insured is an insured or named insured 
  who â€˜hasâ€™ a vehicle involved in the accident.â€Â  Concrete Servs., Inc. v. 
  United States Fid. & Guar. Co., 331 S.C. 506, 512, 498 S.E.2d 865, 868 
  (1998).Â  In order â€œto â€˜haveâ€™ a vehicle involved in the accident as a prerequisite 
  to stacking mean[s] only that a person must be a Class I insured with respect 
  to a vehicle involved in the accident.â€Â  Id. at 513, 498 S.E.2d at 868.Â  
  A Class I insured has been repeatedly defined as the named insured, his spouse 
  and relatives residing in his household.Â  Id.; see also Davidson 
  v. E. Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 245 S.C. 472, 477, 141 S.E.2d 135, 138 (1965) 
  (defining a Class I insured as the â€œnamed insured, his spouse and his or 
  her relatives resident in the same householdâ€) (emphasis added). [5] Â  A Class II insured includes any person using, with the consent 
  of the named insured, the motor vehicle to which the policy applies and a guest 
  in the motor vehicle.Â  Garris v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 280 S.C. 149, 311 
  S.E.2d 723 (1984).
The pertinent inquiry here is whether Crystal is a Class I insured.Â  Specifically, 
  the issue is whether Crystal was a resident relative of the named insuredâ€™s 
  household entitling her to stack UIM benefits under the policy.Â  
Our Supreme Court first analyzed whether a person was a resident 
  relative of the same household as the named insured in Buddin v. Nationwide 
  Mut. Ins. Co., 250 S.C. 332, 157 S.E.2d 633 (1967).Â  In finding a nephew 
  was a â€œrelative resident of the same householdâ€ as his uncle, as that term was 
  used in the uncleâ€™s insurance policy to extend coverage to additional insureds, 
  the Court stated â€œâ€˜a resident of the same household is one, other than a temporary 
  or transient visitor, who lives together with others in the same house for a 
  period of some duration, although he may not intend to remain there permanently.â€™â€Â  
  Id. at 339, 157 S.E.2d at 636 (quoting Hardware Mut. Cas. Co. v. Home 
  Indem. Co., 50 Cal. Rptr. 508, 514 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 1966)); see also 
  Farmers Ins. of Columbus, Inc. v. Taylor, 528 N.E.2d 968, 969 (Ohio Ct. 
  App. 1987) (stating â€œthe word â€˜residentâ€™ as used in the phrase â€˜resident of 
  your household,â€™ [unless otherwise defined in a policy,] refers to one who lives 
  in the home of the named insured for a period of some duration or regularity, 
  although not necessarily there permanently, but excludes a temporary or transient 
  visitor.â€).Â  The Court also noted several factors for possible consideration 
  but stated that none of the factors were determinative of the issue.Â  Buddin, 
  250 S.C. at 338-39, 157 S.E.2d at 636.Â  The factors included:Â  (1) the payment 
  of rent or board; (2) the presence or absence of control over the relative; 
  and (3) whether there was lack of a permanent living arrangement.Â  Id.Â  

This Court has more recently considered whether 
  an individual was a resident relative in Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 
  330 S.C. 578, 500 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. App. 1998), and Richardson v. South Carolina 
  Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 233, 519 S.E.2d 120 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
  In Langford, we recognized the notion of the individualâ€™s intent and 
  noted â€œa person may be a resident relative for insurance purposes even though 
  he does not have an intent to permanently reside with the insured.â€Â  Langford, 
  330 S.C. at 583, 500 S.E.2d at 498.Â Â  
In Richardson, we affirmed the trial courtâ€™s 
  determination that a twenty-five-year-old graduate student was not a resident 
  relative of her fatherâ€™s household, and thus, was not entitled to stack uninsured 
  motorist coverage under her fatherâ€™s policy.Â  The daughter was held to be a 
  â€œtransitory visitor,â€ even though she still had certain connections to her fatherâ€™s 
  household.Â  Richardson, 336 S.C. at 236-37, 519 S.E.2d at 122.Â  In so 
  holding, we noted several factors supporting the trial courtâ€™s finding that 
  the daughter was not a resident of her fatherâ€™s household, including:Â  (1) she 
  kept an exercise machine, some furniture, and seasonal clothes at her fatherâ€™s 
  house; (2) she acknowledged living in various apartments in the seven years 
  preceding the accident; (3) she usually visited her parents once a month for 
  three to four days at a time; (4) she spent only a portion of two summers with 
  her parents in the four years prior to the accident; (5) she filed her own tax 
  returns and claimed herself as a dependent; (6) her tax refund was not sent 
  to her fatherâ€™s house; (7) her driverâ€™s license did not list her fatherâ€™s address; 
  (8) she was registered to vote in a different county than her father; and (9) 
  Richardson worked regularly and claimed income of over $10,000 in each of the 
  two years prior to the accident.Â  Id. at 237, 519 S.E.2d at 122-123.
In State Farm Fire & Cas. Co. v. Breazell, our Supreme Court also 
  discussed, in the context of a homeownerâ€™s policy, whether a foster child was 
  a resident of the foster parentsâ€™ household and adopted a three-factor test 
  for making this determination.Â  State Farm Fire & Cas. Co. v. Breazell, 
  324 S.C. 228, 478 S.E.2d 831 (1996).

  The determination under the . . . test is dependent upon [these] factors:Â  
    (1) living under the same roof; (2) in a close, intimate and informal relationship 
    between the parties; and (3) where the intended duration of the relationship 
    is likely to be substantial, where it is consistent with the informality of 
    the relationship, and from which it is reasonable to conclude that the parties 
    would consider the relationship in contracting about such matters as insurance 
    or in their conduct in reliance thereon.

Id. at 231, 478 S.E.2d at 832.
Notwithstanding the South Carolina appellate courtsâ€™ determinations 
  of resident relative status in the above cases, our courts have not considered 
  the issue of whether a child is a resident relative of a noncustodial parentâ€™s 
  household when the childâ€™s parents are divorced or separated, the child is living 
  with one parent, and custody of the child has been established.Â  Numerous other 
  states have visited this issue with varying results.Â  See generally Carolyn 
  Kelly MacWilliam, Annotation, Who is â€œMemberâ€ or â€œResidentâ€ of Same â€œFamilyâ€ 
  or â€œHouseholdâ€ within No-Fault or Uninsured Motorist Provisions of Motor Vehicle 
  Insurance Policy, 66 A.L.R.5th 269 (1999).Â  
The analysis in cases of this type is generally fact-specific 
  and no bright line test exists for determining under what instances a child 
  is a resident relative of a noncustodial parent.Â  See Griffith v. 
  Sec. Ins. Co. of Hartford, 356 A.2d 94, 97 (Conn. 1975) (stating the problem 
  of deciding whether a person is a member of a particular household is dependent 
  upon the factual circumstances involved and noting the factual circumstances 
  in the cases are so varied that the decisions are of little precedential value); 
  Adams v. Great Am. Ins. Cos., 942 P.2d 1087, 1091 (Wash. Ct. App. 1997) 
  (stating there is no bright line test for determining residency in a household 
  and the inquiry in each case is factual).Â  The fact-specific analysis in the 
  various cases can be attributed to the phrase â€œresident of the same householdâ€ 
  having no absolute or precise meaning.Â  See Buddin, 250 S.C. at 
  338, 157 S.E.2d at 635; Coriasco v. Hutchcraft, 615 N.E.2d 64, 65 (Ill. 
  App. Ct. 1993) (stating the phrase â€œresident of the householdâ€ has no fixed 
  or exact meaning); Pierce v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 627 P.2d 152, 
  154 (Wash. Ct. App. 1981) (â€œThe phrase â€˜residents of the same householdâ€™ has 
  no fixed meaning but varies according to the circumstances of the case.â€).Â  
  The decisions of other courts on this issue have resulted from the application 
  of the facts in the cases before them to a variety of factors. [6] 
In Countryside Cas. Co. v. McCormick, 722 
  S.W.2d 655 (Mo. Ct. App. 1987), the court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision in a declaratory judgment action that a child was a resident of her 
  fatherâ€™s household, even though her mother had been granted custody.Â  The appellate 
  court found that an aggregate of the following factors tended to support the 
  trial courtâ€™s finding:Â  (1) the childâ€™s age; (2) the proximity of the divorced 
  parents; (3) whether reasonable visitation rights had been awarded under the 
  divorce decree; (4) currency of child support payments; (5) the relationship 
  between the parent and the child; (6) whether the child had a separate bedroom 
  and wardrobe; and (7) the frequency of visitation.Â  Id. at 658.Â  The 
  court also noted that the most significant factor in determining residence is 
  custody, but that other factors affect the determination, including periods 
  of residence with the parent and substantial support from the parent.Â  Id. 
  at 657; accord Garrison v. Travelers Ins. Co., 618 A.2d 387 (N.J. 
  Super. Ct. Law Div. 1992) (recognizing and applying the factors discussed in 
  Countryside to find that a nine-year-old was a resident relative of her 
  non-custodial fatherâ€™s household; the child visited her father every other weekend 
  and for extended periods over school holidays in the five months prior to the 
  child being struck by an underinsured automobile).Â Â  
An Illinois court held that the determination of 
  residency in each case includes an analysis of intent, physical presence, and 
  permanency of abode.Â  Coriasco, 615 N.E.2d at 65; see Country 
  Mut. Ins. Co. v. Watson, 274 N.E.2d 136, 138 (Ill. App. Ct. 1971) (â€œThe 
  elements required beyond physical presence are intention and permanency of abode.â€).Â  
  The court applied the facts of the case to these factors and found a minor child 
  to be a resident of her fatherâ€™s household.Â  The childâ€™s parents had divorced 
  and custody had been awarded to the mother.Â  The child â€œresided with her mother 
  except for visitation with her father which occurs principally on weekends and 
  occasionally during the week.â€Â  Coriasco, 615 N.E.2d at 66.Â  The child 
  also kept clothing and personal items at her fatherâ€™s house and had occasionally 
  received mail there. 
In another case, a seventeen-year-old son was found not to be a resident relative 
  of his fatherâ€™s household.Â  Gulf Am. Fire & Cas. Co. v. Azar, 364 
  So. 2d 332 (Ala. Civ. App. 1978).Â  At the time of an accident involving an uninsured 
  motorist, the son had been living with his mother for three months pursuant 
  to the custody arrangements of a divorce decree.Â  The son had visited at his 
  fatherâ€™s home but had not spent the night there.Â  â€œAs these facts indicate, 
  neither [the sonâ€™s] actual or legal residence was in his fatherâ€™s household.â€Â  
  Id. at 334.Â  
In a North Carolina declaratory judgment action 
  to determine a minor childâ€™s entitlement to uninsured motorist coverage under 
  her fatherâ€™s insurance policy, the court held â€œthe evidence discloses that there 
  existed between the father and the minor plaintiff a continuing and substantially 
  integrated family relationship.â€Â  Davis v. Maryland Cas. Co., 331 S.E.2d 
  744, 747 (N.C. Ct. App. 1985).Â  The court pointed to the childâ€™s frequent overnight 
  stays with her father, the provisions made for the keeping of the childâ€™s clothes, 
  personal property, and furniture, and the fatherâ€™s support and healthcare obligations 
  pursuant to a separation agreement.Â  Id. at 745.Â  In addition, the court 
  noted that for insurance purposes a child is not a resident of one parentâ€™s 
  household to the exclusion of the other, but could be a resident of both households.Â  
  Id. at 746; see also Hartford Cas. Ins. Co. v. Phillips, 
  575 S.W.2d 62 (Tex. Civ. App. 1978) (affirming juryâ€™s finding that a fourteen-year-old 
  living with his father was still a resident relative of his motherâ€™s household 
  and pointing out that a finding of residency in one household does not necessarily 
  foreclose that person being a resident of another household).Â  
The Washington Court of Appeals listed four factors 
  to consider in addressing whether a child is a resident of a household:Â  â€œ(1) 
  the intent of the departing person, (2) the formality or informality of the 
  relationship between the person and the members of the household, (3) the relative 
  propinquity of the dwelling units, and (4) the existence of another place of 
  lodging.â€Â  Adams v. Great Am. Ins. Cos., 942 P.2d 1087, 1090 (Wash. Ct. 
  App. 1997) (quoting Pierce v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 627 P.2d 152, 
  155 (Wash. Ct. App. 1981)).Â  Interestingly, the court then went on to frame 
  the question as follows for cases of this type:Â  

  Does the child regularly spend time in the household in question, such that 
    there exists a continuing expectation of the childâ€™s periodic return on intervals 
    regular enough that the household is the childâ€™s home during the time the 
    child is there, as opposed to a place of infrequent and irregular visits.

Adams, 942 P.2d at 1091.
In Midwest Mut. Ins. Co. v. Titus, a Colorado court focused on intent 
  and stated a â€œ[c]onsideration of all relevant circumstances must reveal â€˜some 
  intended presence in the insuredâ€™s home.â€™â€Â  Midwest Mut. Ins. Co. v. Titus, 
  849 P.2d 908, 910 (Colo. Ct. App. 1993) (quoting Wheeler v. Allstate Ins. 
  Co., 814 P.2d 9, 10 (Colo. Ct. App. 1991)).Â  The court listed the factors 
  it would take into account in determining whether an individual is a resident 
  of a household to include the â€œsubjective or declared intent of the individual, 
  the relation between the individual and the members of the household, the existence 
  of a second place of lodging, and the relative permanence or transient nature 
  of the individualâ€™s residence in the household.â€Â  Midwest, 849 P.2d at 
  910.Â  The childâ€™s status as a minor is just one factor to be considered.Â  Id.Â  
  The court also recognized that a child of divorced parents is a resident of 
  the household in which she actually lives but the child may reside in more than 
  one household.Â  Id.Â  
In another case focusing on intent, the Rhode Island Supreme Court stated the 
  test for residency as follows:Â  

  In order to determine if a person is a resident of a particular household, 
    the court must consider whether in the totality of the circumstances that 
    person maintains a physical presence in the household with the intent to remain 
    there for more than a mere transitory period, or that person has a reasonably 
    recent history of physical presence together with circumstances that manifest 
    an intent to return to the residence within a reasonably foreseeable period.

Barricelli v. Am. Universal Ins. Co., 583 
  A.2d 1270, 1271 (R.I. 1990) (quoting Aetna Life & Cas. Co. v. Carrera, 
  577 A.2d 980, 985 (R.I. 1990)).Â  In Barricelli, custody of a minor daughter 
  had been granted to her mother.Â  The daughter lived with her mother for four 
  years and then permanently moved in with her father.Â  The custody decree was 
  not judicially modified.Â  The daughter received her own room in her fatherâ€™s 
  home, registered for and attended school from the fatherâ€™s home, received mail 
  there, and kept most of her personal belongings and clothing there.Â  The father 
  claimed the daughter as a dependent on his tax returns.Â  The daughter â€œmaintained 
  a structured, albeit intermittent, relationshipâ€ with her mother â€œalthough it 
  remained necessary for [the daughter] to pack a suitcase to stay with her mother 
  on the alternate weekends.â€Â  Id. at 1271.Â  The court held the totality 
  of the circumstances showed the impermanence of the daughterâ€™s physical presence 
  in her motherâ€™s household and failed to establish the daughterâ€™s visits to her 
  motherâ€™s home were for anything more than a transitory period.Â  Id. at 
  1272.Â Â Â Â  
In Herbst v. Hansen, 176 N.W.2d 380, 384 (Wis. 1970), the court stated 
  the test for whether a person remains a member of a household is whether the 
  person has intent to return.Â  In this case, the mother had been granted custody 
  of a ten-year-old child pursuant to a decree of legal separation.Â  The issue 
  was whether the child could be considered a resident of the same household as 
  his father under the fatherâ€™s insurance policy.Â  The court found the fatherâ€™s 
  continued support and visitation, coupled with the parentsâ€™ chances for reconciliation, 
  precluded granting summary judgment in favor of the fatherâ€™s insurance carrier 
  given the facts supported a finding that the fatherâ€™s absence was only temporary.Â  
  The court held if a party is not living under the â€œfamily roofâ€ at the time 
  in question then the absence of that party must be of a temporary nature with 
  intent to return.Â  Id.Â  â€œâ€˜Whether the absence from the household is of 
  long or short duration is immaterial except as it may give rise to an inference 
  of intent to remain away permanently or only temporarily.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting 
  Doern v. Crawford, 140 N.W.2d 193, 196 (Wis. 1966)); see also 
  Ohio Cas. Ins. Co. v. Wittkopp, 741 A.2d 619, 622 (N.J. Super. Ct. App. 
  Div. 1999) (â€œAbsence from a parentâ€™s home, even for several months, does not 
  terminate the childâ€™s residency without additional factors.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In Elder v. Metro. Prop. & Cas. Co., 
  851 S.W.2d 557 (Mo. Ct. App. 1993), a twenty-year-old son was held not to reside 
  with his father for insurance purposes.Â  The son contended he was an unemancipated 
  minor and should be considered a resident of his fatherâ€™s household even though 
  he lived with his mother on a permanent basis and his parents were separated 
  and living apart.Â  The court found the evidence suggested the son was not truly 
  unemancipated since he was not attending secondary school or an institution 
  of vocational or higher education.Â  Id. at 561.Â  Custody had been placed 
  with the mother and the son had not stayed with his father in the two and a 
  half years preceding the accident.Â  The court stated custody was the most important 
  factor in determining residency.Â  Id. at 560.Â  The court also stated 
  â€œ[r]esidence is a matter of intention and depends on a personâ€™s physical location.â€Â  
  Id. at 561; cf. Amica Mut. Ins. Co. v. Donegal Mut. Ins. Co., 
  545 A.2d 343 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1988) (holding residence in a household under the 
  policy in question was a matter of physical fact and not intention). 
As evident from these cases, there is no single 
  test to determine whether a minor child is a resident of a noncustodial parentâ€™s 
  household for purposes of determining UIM benefits.Â  Rather, the courts generally 
  look at the facts and circumstances of each case in totality to determine the 
  childâ€™s residency.Â  In this case, the record supports the refereeâ€™s conclusion 
  that Crystal was not a resident relative of the Horneâ€™s household.
In support of their contention that Crystal was 
  a resident relative, the Hornes cite the following evidence: (1) Crystalâ€™s visits 
  were planned, coordinated, and expected; (2) Crystal received mail at her fatherâ€™s 
  address; (3) Crystalâ€™s custodial setting was established pursuant to the 1988 
  divorce decree; (4) the Hornes maintained a room prepared with furniture, lamps, 
  and a trash can they purchased and designated for Crystalâ€™s use when she was 
  with them; (5) Crystal kept clothes, toiletries, and other items at the Hornesâ€™ 
  house; (6) Crystal ate meals with and prepared by Mr. Horne; (7) Crystal washed 
  clothes at the Hornesâ€™ house; (8) Crystal had unrestricted access to the entire 
  house while she lived there and was not required to obtain permission before 
  returning to the house; and (9) Mr. Horne maintained health insurance for Crystal 
  and was current on child support payments. Â The Hornes argue this evidence, 
  especially the planned and coordinated nature of Crystalâ€™s visits, demonstrates 
  residency and show Crystal â€œhad every intent to continue the relationship with 
  her father without ever considering ending it.â€ The special referee noted the 
  evidence established Crystal had a close relationship with Mr. and Mrs. Horne 
  but it did not translate into a finding that Crystal was a resident of their 
  household.Â  See Griffith v. Sec. Ins. Co. of Hartford, 356 A.2d 
  94, 96 (Conn. 1975) (stating evidence indicating a close paternal relationship 
  does not necessarily support an additional finding that the parties are members 
  of the same household).
Crystalâ€™s parents divorced in 1988 and sole custody 
  had been granted to Williams.Â  Crystal moved with Williams to Conway in 1992 
  and they have resided there since that time.Â  Mr. and Mrs. Horne have remained 
  in the Saluda/Greenwood area.Â  In the year prior to the accident Crystal had 
  stayed with her father on a maximum of three occasions, for a total of approximately 
  fourteen days, but at the time of the accident Crystal had not visited her father 
  for over three months. [7] Â  Crystal, however, could not 
  testify with any certainty whether she had visited her father during the 1996 
  Thanksgiving holiday. 
Crystal did not maintain everyday clothes or other 
  possessions at her fatherâ€™s house.Â  If any items had been left behind or forgotten 
  at her fatherâ€™s house, such as clothes or cosmetics, it was because Crystal 
  did not need the items or did not use them anymore.Â  Any mail Crystal may have 
  received at her fatherâ€™s house came only from her mother.Â  Crystalâ€™s healthcare 
  providers were located in Conway and Crystalâ€™s driverâ€™s license listed her address 
  as her motherâ€™s home.Â  Williams claimed Crystal as a dependent on her tax return. 

Crystal was seventeen years old at the time of 
  the accident and worked full-time at a Burger King restaurant close to her home 
  in Conway.Â  She was scheduled to work on the day after the accident.Â  Crystal 
  began spending significantly less time with her father once she quit school 
  in 1996 after her ninth-grade year and began working at Burger King.Â  Crystal 
  spent only a few days in Saluda during the summer of 1996 and did not spend 
  the entire summer as she had in previous years.Â  Mr. and Mrs. Horne admitted 
  Crystalâ€™s visits became less frequent through the years.Â  When Crystal started 
  working, the pattern of visitation changed, and she did not visit unless she 
  had time off from work.Â  However, Crystal had time off from her job at Burger 
  King the weekend before the accident but she did not leave the Conway/Myrtle 
  Beach area. 
Crystal packed a suitcase when she traveled to 
  Saluda and spent the night with other family members besides her father during 
  her visits. Sometimes Crystal would visit her other relatives before going to 
  her fatherâ€™s house.Â  During her four- or five-day stay in Saluda over the Christmas 
  holiday before the accident, Crystal spent nights with her two aunts and her 
  grandmother.Â  Crystal shared a room at her fatherâ€™s house with her sister.Â  
  Moreover, Crystalâ€™s stepsister also used the bedroom when she would visit her 
  mother, Mrs. Horne.Â  The stepsister did not have to ask Crystal for permission 
  to use the bedroom. Â Crystal had unrestricted access to her fatherâ€™s house when 
  she was there but her father required her to call before she visited so he would 
  know she was coming and Crystal never just â€œshowed up.â€ 
The special referee properly found Crystal was 
  not a resident relative of her fatherâ€™s household.Â  The evidence in the record 
  reasonably supports his decision and is not â€œreasonably susceptible of the opposite 
  conclusion only.â€Â  Hiott, 329 S.C. at 529, 496 S.E.2d at 421.Â  We agree 
  with the referee that while Crystal had a close relationship with her father 
  and stepmother, she was not a resident of their household.Â  Crystalâ€™s short, 
  infrequent visits to Saluda, scattered with her overnight stays with other relatives, 
  demonstrate the transient nature of Crystalâ€™s residence in her fatherâ€™s household.Â  
  Buddin, 250 S.C. at 339, 157 S.E.2d at 636; Midwest, 849 P.2d 
  at 910.Â  Crystal could visit Saluda only when she was able to get off of work.Â Â Â  
  Her work schedule at the time of the accident precluded an expectation of Crystalâ€™s 
  return to the home with any regularity.Â  Any personal items left at her fatherâ€™s 
  home do not indicate an intent to return there with any regularity given the 
  items were either forgotten or were not needed any longer.Â  In some respects, 
  Crystal had even less contacts with her fatherâ€™s household than did the daughter 
  in Richardson, 336 S.C. at 237, 519 S.E.2d at 122-23 (finding the daughter 
  was not a resident of her fatherâ€™s household even though she kept furniture 
  and an exercise bike at her fatherâ€™s home and usually visited her parents once 
  a month for three or four days at a time).Â  The circumstances present in this 
  case do not manifest Crystalâ€™s intent to return to her fatherâ€™s household within 
  a reasonably foreseeable period or her intent to remain there for more than 
  a transitory period.Â  Barricelli, 583 A.2d at 1271.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, because Crystal was not a resident relative of the named insuredâ€™s 
  household, she was not a Class I insured entitled to stack UIM benefits.Â  See 
  Concrete Servs., 331 S.C. at 509, 498 S.E.2d at 866 (â€œThe right to stack 
  is available only to a Class I insured.â€).Â  The special refereeâ€™s judgment is
AFFIRMED. [8] 
HEARN, C.J. and STILWELL, J., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â Â  Crystal was apparently confused during her deposition about her 
    stated address and the address listed on her driverâ€™s license.Â  Crystal stated 
    she lived at 4134 Highland Drive, Aynor, at the time of the accident and that 
    this was the address found on her driverâ€™s license.Â  Crystal had earlier testified 
    she and her mother â€œmoved to 4134 in Aynorâ€ after living at an address in 
    Conway. However, the copy of Crystalâ€™s driverâ€™s license included in the record 
    lists her address as Plum Tree Lane, Conway.Â  Any discrepancy between Crystalâ€™s 
    stated address and that found on her driverâ€™s license does not affect our 
    analysis.

 
   
    [2] Â  The underinsured motorist endorsement of the policy issued to Mrs. 
    Horne stated Auto-Owners â€œwill pay damages for:Â  (1) Bodily injury sustained 
    by any person occupying or getting in or out of an automobile . . . covered 
    by the Liability Coverage of the Policy, provided such person is legally entitled 
    to recover such damages from the owner or driver of an [under]insured motor 
    vehicle.â€ 

 
   
    [3] Â  In their brief, the Hornes argued the referee erred in finding Crystal 
    was not also a named insured under the Auto-Owners policy.Â  However, at oral 
    argument the Hornes abandoned this argument.Â  Thus, we will not address it.

 
   [4] Â  Section 38-77-160 provides 
    in part:


  If, however, an insured or named insured is protected by uninsured 
    or underinsured motorist coverage in excess of the basic limits, the policy 
    shall provide that the insured or named insured is protected only to the extent 
    of the coverage he has on the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  If none of 
    the insuredâ€™s or named insuredâ€™s vehicles is involved in the accident, coverage 
    is available only to the extent of coverage on any one of the vehicles with 
    the excess or underinsured coverage.


  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002).

 
   
    [5]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Even though Davidson defined two classes of insured 
    persons, the decision did not involve an issue of stacking.Â  In Davidson, 
    the two classes of insureds were culled from the definition of the term â€œinsuredâ€ 
    under section 46-750.11 of the 1962 South Carolina Code of Laws.Â  Davidson, 
    245 S.C. at 476-77, 141 S.E.2d at 137-38.Â  This section defined â€œinsuredâ€ 
    as the â€œnamed insured and, while resident of the same household, the spouse 
    of any such named insured and relatives of either . . . , and any person 
    who uses, with the consent . . . of the named insured, the motor vehicle to 
    which the policy applies and a guest in such a motor vehicle . . . .â€Â  S.C. 
    Code Ann. Â§ 46-750.11 (1962) (emphasis added).Â  The current definition of 
    insured found in section 38-77-30 is nearly identical to the former definition 
    under which the Davidson court formed the separate classes of insureds. 
    Â However, it appears that later stacking cases have pared down the language 
    of a Class I insured to include only the named insured, his spouse, and relatives 
    residing in his household, rather than relatives of either the named 
    insured or the spouse of the named insured.Â  See, e.g., Concrete 
    Servs., Inc., 331 S.C. at 514, 498 S.E.2d at 868-69 (stating that to qualify 
    as a Class I insured an individual must be the spouse or relative of the named 
    insured); Garris v. Cincinnati Ins. Co., 280 S.C. 149, 156, 311 S.E.2d 
    723, 727 (1984) (defining the first class of insureds to include the named 
    insured, his spouse and relatives residing in his household); Richardson 
    v. South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 233, 235, 519 S.E.2d 
    120, 122 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œA Class I insured is a named insured, his spouse, 
    and relatives residing in his household.â€).Â  
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A literal and 
    exacting application of the definition of a Class I insured in the stacking 
    cases after Davidson raises an interesting issue in the present case.Â  
    Obviously, the question of whether someone is a resident relative requires 
    that residency and relationship be shown.Â  Since Crystal is not a spouse of 
    Mrs. Horne, the named insured, in order for Crystal to stack UIM benefits 
    she must be Mrs. Horneâ€™s relative.Â  However, Crystal may not be Mrs. Horneâ€™s 
    relative.Â  Ordinarily, a relative is defined as a person connected by blood, 
    marriage, or adoption.Â  Inman v. South Carolina Ins. Co., 300 S.C. 
    550, 551-52, 389 S.E.2d 173, 174 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  But â€œ[i]n the context of 
    insurance contracts, â€˜relativeâ€™ has been reasonably interpreted as restricted 
    to those related by consanguinity and excluding those related by affinity.â€Â  
    Forner v. Butler, 319 S.C. 275, 278, 460 S.E.2d 425, 427 (Ct. App. 
    1995).Â  
  However, even though Crystal 
    may not be Mrs. Horneâ€™s relative based on Forner, Auto-Owners did not 
    raise this issue in its complaint.Â  In its brief, Auto-Owners states the â€œSpecial 
    Referee correctly held that Crystal Horne was not living with her father and 
    the named insured (stepmother) at the time of the . . . accident.â€Â  Thus, 
    because Crystal is certainly Mr. Horneâ€™s relative, and thereby is entitled 
    to stack if she is a resident, we will address whether Crystal is a resident 
    of her fatherâ€™s, and Mrs. Horneâ€™s, household for stacking purposes.Â  Moreover, 
    in this case, the household of one (Mr. Horne) is the household of the other 
    (Mrs. Horne).

 
   
    [6]  The insurance policies discussed in most of the following cases in 
    the remainder of this opinion usually provide coverage for a named insured 
    and his or her relatives or family members.Â  The broad issue in each case 
    centers on whether a child is an insured under a parentâ€™s insurance policy.Â  
    The terms â€œrelativesâ€ and â€œfamily membersâ€ are consistently defined in the 
    insurance policies as â€œa resident of the same householdâ€ as the named insured.Â  
    The present case is distinguishable because the policy issued to Mrs. Horne 
    does not define a â€œrelativeâ€ or a â€œfamily member.â€Â  However, this is of no 
    consequence because we are not concerned with the definition of either term 
    under an insurance policy.Â  Our inquiry focuses on whether Crystal is a resident 
    of the Horneâ€™s household based on statutory and common law concepts of stacking.Â  
    The following cases are nonetheless instructive given the policy language 
    in the cases is so similar to our notion of a Class I insured as being a resident 
    relative of the same household as the named insured.Â Â  

 
   
    [7] Â  The three occasions in 1996 included a few days in the summertime, 
    Thanksgiving, and Christmas.Â  The Hornes dispute the refereeâ€™s finding of 
    fourteen days, arguing Crystal spent a weekend with her father approximately 
    one month before the accident.Â  However, the Hornes point to an isolated portion 
    of Crystalâ€™s stepbrotherâ€™s testimony for this proposition.Â  In context, her 
    stepbrotherâ€™s testimony refers to Crystalâ€™s visits on the weekends before 
    Crystal moved to Conway in 1992.Â  Even assuming sixteen days were correct, 
    the two-day difference would not affect our analysis.

 
   
    [8] Â  The Hornes also urge this Court to hold that a minor unemancipated 
    child can be a resident of two households.Â  See, e.g., Davis v. 
    Maryland Cas. Co., 331 S.E.2d 744, 746-47 (N.C. Ct. App. 1985) (stating 
    it is not required that a minor be a resident of one parentâ€™s household to 
    the exclusion of the other and that a minor could be a resident of two separate 
    households).Â  We need not specifically rule on this issue given the facts 
    in this case do not demonstrate Crystal resided in her fatherâ€™s household.Â  
    However, implicit in this decision is the recognition that a child of divorced 
    parents may be a resident of two households given Crystal is surely a resident 
    of her motherâ€™s household.Â  Cf. Cook v. Fed. Ins. Co., 263 S.C. 
    575, 582, 211 S.E.2d 881, 884 (1975) (â€œA person may have only one domicile, 
    but may have several residences.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,                                          
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jimmy Lee Ellison,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3675Â Â Â 
Heard June 11, 2003 â€“ Filed September 15, 2003 

VACATED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender 
  Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of SC Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant. 

Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Charles H. Richardson, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, 
  Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  In this opinion we must decide 
  whether the circuit court had subject matter jurisdiction to convict Jimmy Lee 
  Ellison of second-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor.Â  We hold 
  the indictment as originally drafted and as amended failed to confer such jurisdiction 
  and vacate Ellisonâ€™s conviction.Â  
BACKGROUND
Ellison was indicted following an allegation 
  that he raped a 13 year old girl.Â  Both the caption of the indictment and the 
  title preceding the text in the body of the indictment stated that the offense 
  was â€œCriminal sexual conduct with a minor (first degree).â€Â  The language in 
  the body of the indictment alleged Ellison â€œdid commit, or attempt to commit, 
  a sexual battery in and upon [Victim], age thirteen . . . by using aggravated 
  force and aggravated coercion upon her and assaulting her with the intent to 
  commit sexual battery with the said [Victim].â€Â  The indictment further stated 
  Ellisonâ€™s conduct was a violation of section 16-3-655 of the South Carolina 
  Code, the statute prohibiting CSC with minors.Â  
At the onset of trial, the State moved to amend the 
  statutory reference, asserting it intended to charge Ellison with first-degree 
  CSC and that the statute referenced was merely an error.Â  When the court inquired, 
  defense counsel stated he was aware the State intended to charge first-degree 
  CSC and that the amendment would make no difference in the presentation of his 
  defense.Â  The court then permitted the amendment without objection.Â  
While conferencing proposed jury instructions after the close 
  of the evidence, the State requested the court submit second-degree CSC as a 
  lesser-included offense of first-degree CSC.Â  The State reasoned that the jury 
  might believe the victim but not be convinced the circumstances rose to the 
  level of aggravated force.Â  The court questioned the Stateâ€™s decision not to 
  charge second-degree CSC with a minor, which would have made proof of force 
  or coercion unnecessary. Â Concern was also expressed that the jury might 
  acquit Ellison if they thought Victim â€œconsentedâ€ to the encounter.Â  Defense 
  counsel noted he intended to argue the alleged event did not occur at all, not 
  that it was consensual.Â  The defense thus objected to the submission of any 
  charge other than first-degree CSC, and the State elected to proceed on that 
  charge alone.Â  
During Ellisonâ€™s closing argument, the State objected to 
  a comment on the ground that it invited the jury to disregard evidence. Â After 
  closing arguments, the court, on its own initiative, concluded the defense 
  had introduced the issue of Victimâ€™s consent in its closing argument and decided, 
  over defense objection, to charge second-degree CSC with a minor as a lesser-included 
  offense of first-degree CSC. Â The jury found Ellison guilty of second-degree 
  CSC with a minor.Â  
DISCUSSION
Ellison argues the trial court lacked subject matter 
  jurisdiction to convict him of second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a 
  minor because it is not a lesser-included offense of the charge for which he 
  was indicted.Â  We agree, and further hold that the indictment fails independently 
  to vest the court with subject matter jurisdiction on the charge for which Ellison 
  was convicted.Â  
â€œA criminal defendant is entitled to be tried only 
  on indicted offenses.â€Â  State v. Jones, 342 S.C. 248, 251, 536 S.E.2d 
  396, 397 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In South Carolina, â€œit is a rule of universal observance 
  in administering the criminal law that a defendant must be convicted, if convicted 
  at all, of the particular offense charged in the bill of indictment.â€Â  State 
  v. Cody, 180 S.C. 417, 423, 186 S.E. 165, 167 (1936).Â  â€œAn indictment is 
  sufficient if it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense intended 
  to be charged and apprises the defendant what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  
  State v. Wilkes, 353 S.C. 462, 465, 578 S.E.2d 717, 718 (2003).Â  â€œFurther, 
  an indictment is sufficient if the offense is stated with sufficient certainty 
  and particularity to enable the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and 
  the defendant to know what he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead 
  an acquittal or conviction thereon.â€Â  Id.Â  
The body of the indictment here alleged Ellison committed 
  a sexual battery on a 13 year old.Â  A person who commits a sexual battery on 
  a person â€œwho is fourteen years of age or less but who is at least eleven years 
  of ageâ€ is guilty of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-655(2) 
  (2003).Â  However, the caption of the indictment and the title to the indictmentâ€™s 
  body stated the alleged crime was first-degree CSC with a minor, a crime involving 
  prohibited sexual conduct with a person under the age of 11.Â  Â§ 16-3-655(1).Â  

The indictment is even more complicated because the body 
  also contains factual allegations apparently sufficient to charge both first-degree 
  CSC by alleging Ellison used aggravated force and second-degree CSC by alleging 
  Ellison used aggravated coercion.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-652(1)(a) (2003) (a 
  person who commits a sexual battery by use of aggravated force is guilty of 
  first-degree CSC); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-653(1) (2003) (a person who commits 
  a sexual battery by use of aggravated coercion is guilty of second-degree CSC).Â  
  The body of the indictment does not specifically state the name of the offense 
  Ellison allegedly committed.Â  Further confusing the issue, the indictment was 
  amended at the beginning of trial to change the statutory reference from the 
  general statute prohibiting CSC with minors to the statute prohibiting first-degree 
  CSC.Â  
Our supreme court recently reviewed the sufficiency of an 
  indictment with similar difficulties.Â  In Cohen v. State, 354 S.C. 563, 
  582 S.E.2d 403 (2003), the indictment alleged Willie Cohen engaged in CSC with 
  a minor.Â  The body of the indictment as well as its title and the indictmentâ€™s 
  caption all identified the crime as CSC with a minor in the first degree.Â  However, 
  the body of the indictment also stated the victim was 11 years old.Â  Id. 
  at ___, 582 S.E.2d at 404.Â  The supreme court noted the indictment was insufficient 
  to charge Cohen with first-degree CSC with a minor because the victim was 11 
  years old, not less than 11 as the statute requires.Â  Id.Â  The court 
  went on to explain why the trial court also lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  to accept Cohenâ€™s guilty plea on the charge of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  


The question then becomes whether the indictment otherwise 
  sufficiently states the offense of second degree CSC with a minor.Â  The indictment 
  appears to sufficiently allege second degree CSC with a minor because it charges 
  that respondent engaged in a sexual battery with a victim of eleven years of 
  age.Â  However, the body of the indictment includes the language â€œcriminal sexual 
  conduct with a minor in the first degree.â€Â  (Emphasis added).Â  The inclusion 
  of the â€œfirst degreeâ€ language is not a scrivenerâ€™s error given that the title 
  and caption of the indictment both indicate the indictment is for first degree 
  CSC with a minor.

* * * *

Further, the indictment does not sufficiently inform the 
  court as to what judgment to pronounce. . . .Â  Therefore the plea court was 
  without subject matter jurisdiction to accept respondentâ€™s plea to second degree 
  CSC with a minor.

Id. at ___, 582 S.E.2d at 405.
Both the caption of the indictment and the title 
  preceding the body indicated Ellison was charged with first-degree CSC with 
  a minor, a crime that was not alleged, factually or by name, in the body of 
  the indictment.Â  The body of the indictment contained a statutory reference 
  indicating Ellisonâ€™s conduct was a violation of the statute prohibiting CSC 
  with minors, but did not identify a crime by name.Â  However, the body of the 
  indictment contained allegations sufficient to accuse Ellison of second-degree 
  CSC with a minor and first and second-degree CSC.Â  Then, at the beginning of 
  trial, the indictment was amended to change the statutory reference to the section 
  prohibiting first-degree CSC, and the assistant solicitor indicated this change 
  was no surprise to Ellison as it was the intended charge all along.Â  By this 
  point, if not before, it was unclear what judgment the court could pronounce 
  and sentence it could impose, as was the case in Cohen.Â  This fact is 
  evidenced by the courtâ€™s submission of second-degree CSC with a minor to the 
  jury as a lesser-included offense.Â  It is unclear whether any conviction could 
  be had on this indictment.Â  But, even if it could have supported a conviction 
  for first-degree CSC, it did not confer jurisdiction on the charge of second-degree 
  CSC with a minor because it is not a lesser-included offense of first-degree
CSC.  
The test to determine whether an offense is a lesser-included 
  offense of another is whether the greater offense contains all of the elements 
  of the lesser offense.Â  Joseph v. State, 351 S.C. 551, 555, 571 S.E.2d 
  280, 282 (2002).Â  Because second-degree CSC with a minor requires the victim 
  be between the ages of 11 and 14, it is not a lesser-included offense of first-degree 
  CSC, which contains no element regarding the victimâ€™s age.Â  Viewing this indictment 
  with a â€œpractical eyeâ€ we are compelled to conclude the court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction to convict Ellison of second-degree CSC with a minor.Â  See 
  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1993) (noting â€œthat 
  in viewing the sufficiency of an indictment we must look at the issue with a 
  practical eye in view of the surrounding circumstancesâ€).Â  
 VACATED. 
  [1] 
    
 HEARN, C.J., and CONNOR, J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because of our resolution of this issue, we need not address 
    Ellisonâ€™s remaining issue.

  obligations under the assigned risk agreement should automatically terminate 
  when an insured obtains Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance on the voluntary market.Â  
  Yet, as indicated in Section III, Paragraph 2 of NCCIâ€™s South Carolina Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Insurance Plan, the assigned risk policy itself must be properly 
  cancelled in accordance with the procedures outlined in the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act and corresponding regulations.
The proper procedures for canceling a 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance policy in South Carolina are found in Regulations 
  67-405 and 67-406.Â  These regulations require that when an insurer wishes to 
  cancel a policy, the insurer shall immediately notify the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commission by filing a Policy Cancellation Notice, Form WC-89-06-09-A, with 
  the NCCI.Â  The Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance policy is deemed continuous until 
  the cancellation notice is duly filed and, even then, cancellation is not effective 
  until after thirty days from the date NCCI receives the Form WC-89-06-09-A.Â  
  See 25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-406(E)-(F) (Supp. 2002).Â  No state law 
  or regulation provides for automatic cancellation of a Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  policy.
Even considering NCCIâ€™s Insurance Plan and Assigned 
  Risk Supplement, Travelers is the proper carrier.Â  No advisory opinion of the 
  NCCI has the force or effect of a law or regulation in South Carolina.Â  The 
  NCCI rules do not supersede the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act or 
  the regulations promulgated thereunder.Â  NCCI is subjugated to the law in South 
  Carolina.Â  The NCCI rules relied on by Travelers do not have the force or effect 
  of law in South Carolina.
The majority opinion is infected with 
  expository error.Â  Because the NCCI rules have been approved by the Chief Insurance 
  Commissioner, the majority elevates the NCCI rules to co-equal status with the 
  regulations approved by the South Carolina General Assembly in the field of 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation.Â  The imprimatur of the Chief Insurance Commissioner is 
  nonefficacious when juxtaposed to approval of a regulation by the South Carolina 
  General Assembly.Â  Is there a factual or legalistic harmonious nexus inter 
  sese the NCCI rules and legislatively approved regulations?Â  In fact, 
  it is not a vel non because the NCCI rules inevitably occupy an 
  inferior status.
The applicable statutory and regulatory provisions 
  of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act govern the determination of 
  coverage in this case.

  
    
      II.Â  IDENTITY OF PROPER CARRIER
      A.Â  Travelers had not Canceled Policy 
  at Time of Accident
    
  

Travelers issued an assigned risk policy to Willowglen 
  with the effective dates of August 24, 1997 through August 24, 1998.Â  Travelers 
  accepted the September 6, 1997 claim of Marty Avant and began paying benefits 
  under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Substantial evidence in the record indicates 
  that Travelers had not initiated cancellation of the assigned risk policy covering 
  Willowglen at the time of the September 6, 1997 accident.
Only Travelersâ€™ obligations under the assignment agreement 
  would have automatically terminated when Willowglen obtained Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  insurance on the voluntary market.Â  This did not occur on July 1, 1997 as found 
  by the Commissioner.Â  When Willowglen renewed its voluntary coverage with United 
  Heartland on July 1, 1997, the only holdings covered under the policy were its 
  Wisconsin holdings.
Amy Gilland testified that Travelers issued a renewal 
  quotation on June 19, 1997.Â  On July 3, 1997, Travelers received a partial renewal 
  payment from Willowglen in the amount of $466.03.Â  The quoted premium was $46,603.00.Â  
  According to Gilland, the partial payment was intended to be a full payment, 
  but the check was mistakenly written for the wrong amount.Â  On August 13, 1997, 
  Willowglen issued a second check for the balance of the full premium to renew 
  the policy insuring Willowglen.Â  Subsequently, Travelers issued the renewal 
  policy with effective dates of August 24, 1997 to August 24, 1998.Â  The timing 
  is significant.Â  Willowglen did not decide to add South Carolina as an endorsement 
  to its United Heartland policy until after Willowglen had already renewed the 
  assigned risk policy with Travelers and fully paid the premium.Â  According to 
  Paul Hindtgen at United Heartland, notice of the new endorsement was sent to 
  the NCCI on or about August 27, 1997.Â  The effective date of this endorsement 
  was July 1, 1997.Â  Travelers was not notified of the endorsement and did not 
  cancel the assigned risk policy covering Willowglen.
To cancel the policy with Willowglen, Travelers was 
  required to follow the explicit cancellation procedure set out in Regulations 
  67-405 and 67-406.Â  According to Regulation 67-405(E), â€œ[i]f the employer fails 
  to renew its insurance, or the insurer cancels the policy, the employerâ€™s insurer 
  shall immediately notify the Commission that it no longer insures the employer 
  by filing a notice of termination with the Commission.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. 
  Reg. 67-405(E) (1990).Â  Regulation 67-406 provides in pertinent part:

B.Â  The insurance carrier shall file a . . . notice of termination 
  directly with the NCCI.Â  The date of receipt by the NCCI is deemed the date 
  of filing with the Commission.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
E.Â  Workersâ€™ compensation insurance is deemed continuous 
  until notice of termination is filed according to R.67-405 and as provided in 
  F below.
F.Â  To cancel workersâ€™ compensation insurance coverage, 
  . . . the insurance carrier shall file with the NCCI an NCCI Form WC 89 06 09 
  A. 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . .
  
(2)Â  Insurance expiration, termination or cancellation shall not be effective 
  until after thirty days from the date of receipt by NCCI of the NCCI Form WC 
  89 06 09 A.
  

25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-406 (Supp. 2002).Â  NCCI 
  acknowledges that cancellation of a Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance policy is 
  regulated by state law.Â  See NCCI Basic Manual, Rule X(A).
Travelers did not file 
  a notice of cancellation form with the NCCI at any time prior to the September 
  6, 1997 accident.Â  Travelers became aware of the existence of voluntary coverage 
  as early as January 5, 1998.Â  The testimony from Amy Gilland and Joel Scott 
  shows that notice of cancellation was received by the Commission on February 
  13, 1998, with an effective date of cancellation of March 19, 1998.Â  This unequivocal 
  notice that Travelersâ€™ policy was canceled effective March 19, 1998 is contained 
  in the record.Â  On April 2, 1998, Travelers sent a second notice of cancellation 
  to Willowglen confirming the policy was cancelled effective March 19, 1998.Â  
  Travelers did not, at any time prior to May 7, 1999, notify Willowglen or United 
  Heartland that it intended to contest coverage for the Avant claim, even though 
  Travelers was aware as early as January 5, 1998, that there was duplicate coverage.Â  
  While Travelers later attempted to change the effective cancellation date to 
  August 24, 1997, by sending a subsequent notice of cancellation on June 5, 1998, 
  the second notice is null and void because the earlier notice had already cancelled 
  the policy.Â  Travelers was attempting to cancel a policy that had been canceled 
  three months earlier.Â  An insurance policy cannot be cancelled twice.Â  Moreover, 
  Regulation 67-406(F)(2) states that cancellation â€œshall not be effectiveâ€ until 
  thirty days after the proper notice of cancellation form is filed with the
NCCI.
Additionally, Travelers issued a new 
  policy to Willowglen after Willowglen had been insured by United Heartland on 
  the voluntary market.Â  Therefore, even if Travelers had cancelled the policy 
  in effect at the time Willowglen obtained a voluntary policy in July 1997, the 
  new Travelers policy issued in August 1997 would have been in effect on September 
  6, 1997.
The Travelers policy had not been canceled and 
  was in effect at the time of Avantâ€™s September 6, 1997 accident.Â  The Travelers 
  policy remained in effect until March 19, 1998.
B. Â Travelers Policy had Later Effective 
  Date
When Avant was injured on September 6, 
  1997, Willowglen was seemingly covered by two insurance policies.Â  The Travelers 
  policy became effective on August 24, 1997 and remained in effect until March 
  19, 1998.Â  The record reveals United Heartland issued a policy covering Willowglen, 
  with an effective date of July 1, 1997.Â  In such cases, Regulation 67-409 determines 
  which carrier is liable for benefits.Â  See 25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-409 
  (1990).Â  Pursuant to Regulation 67-409(A), â€œ[w]hen duplicate or dual coverage 
  exists by reason of two different insurance carriers issuing two policies to 
  the same employer securing the same liability, the Commission shall presume 
  the policy with the later effective date is in force and the earlier policy 
  terminated on the effective date of the later policy.â€Â  (Emphasis added). This 
  mandatory language creates an irrebuttable presumption that the Travelers policy 
  with the effective date of August 24, 1997 was in force on September 6, 1997, 
  not the United Heartland policy.
This presumption is supported by the fact that 
  Travelers accepted Avantâ€™s claim for the September 6, 1997 accident and paid 
  benefits in excess of $40,000, even after discovering the dual coverage issue 
  in early January 1998.Â  Travelers did not pursue legal action until May 7, 1999, 
  when Travelers filed a motion requesting the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission 
  to identify the proper carrier for the Avant claim.Â  Willowglen continued to 
  pay and Travelers continued to accept premiums after issuing the August 1997-98 
  renewal policy.
Because the renewal policy issued by Travelers 
  effective August 24, 1997 has a later effective date than the United Heartland 
  policy issued July 1, 1997, the law presumes the United Heartland policy was 
  terminated after August 24, 1997.Â  Therefore, by virtue of Regulation 67-409, 
  only the Travelers policy was in effect on September 6, 1997.Â  The Act and the 
  regulations clearly presume the Travelers policy covers Avantâ€™s accident on 
  September 6, 1997.
C.Â  Retroactive Cancellation of Workersâ€™ Compensation not 
  Permitted 
 Under these Facts
Travelers argues the â€œcircuit court erred 
  in finding that retroactive cancellation of a policy is not permissible under 
  any circumstances.â€Â  This is a misstatement of the judgeâ€™s order.Â  The judge 
  held: â€œSouth Carolina law does not permit retroactive cancellation of workersâ€™ 
  compensation insurance except in one limited circumstance: where there are dual 
  policies with the same effective date.â€Â  (emphasis in judgeâ€™s order).Â  
  This is a correct statement of law.Â  The only provision for retroactive cancellation 
  of a Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance policy is found at 25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 
  67-409(B) (1990).Â  â€œWhen both policies carry the same effective date, one policy 
  may be cancelled by filing a notice of termination retroactive to the date of 
  the policyâ€™s inception.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Reg. 67-409(B) (1990).
The general rule is found at 25A S.C. Code Ann. 
  Reg. 67-406(F)(2) (Supp. 2002): â€œInsurance expiration, termination or cancellation 
  shall not be effective until after thirty days from the date of receipt by NCCI 
  of the NCCI Form WC 89 06 09 A.â€Â  Travelers cites no statute, regulation, or 
  case that would permit Travelers to retroactively cancel a Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  insurance policy under any other circumstance.
The Travelers policy and the United Heartland policy 
  at issue do not have the â€œsame effective date.â€Â  Accordingly, the law does not 
  permit Travelers to cancel its policy retroactively.
Furthermore, public policy dictates that 
  retroactive cancellation of Workersâ€™ Compensation insurance be the exception, 
  not the rule.Â  Professor Larson articulated: â€œIn view of the essential role 
  of insurance in the compensation process, and the serious potential effects 
  of noninsurance on both employer and employee, requirements for cancellation 
  of insurance are generally exacting, and are strictly construed and applied.â€Â  
  9 Arthur Larson & Lex K. Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law 
  Â§ 150.03[1] (2000) (emphasis added).Â  Thus, South Carolinaâ€™s regulations on 
  cancellation should be strictly construed and applied.Â  These regulations cannot 
  be circumvented by an advisory policy.Â  Cancellation of a Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  insurance policy is regulated by state law.
CONCLUSION
Travelers is the proper carrier with 
  coverage.Â  United Heartland has no liability for benefits in this case under 
  the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  I VOTE to AFFIRM 
  the order of the circuit court judge finding that Travelers is solely responsible 
  for providing coverage of Avantâ€™s claim.

 
   
    [1] Â  Moreover, as a policy matter, to deny the effect of the WCIP in 
    this case would encourage voluntary insurers to receive premiums and set effective 
    dates prior to the effective date of an assigned risk policy.

 
   
    [2]  It should also be noted that the record does not definitively show 
    that United made the proper filing with NCCI changing the effective date of 
    its voluntary policy, nor did United ever cancel its policy.Â  See 25A 
    S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406(D) (Supp. 2002) (stating the insurance carrier 
    shall file with NCCI a report of coverage and endorsements within thirty days 
    of the policyâ€™s effective date).Â  Thus, the effective date of Unitedâ€™s policy 
    remains July 1, 1997.Â Â  

 
   
    [3] Â Â  Strelka stated Willowglenâ€™s intent, through his agency, was to 
    place its workersâ€™ compensation insurance in the voluntary market and allow 
    the Travelers policy to lapse.Â  However, Willowglen mistakenly paid premiums 
    to Travelers upon receiving the renewal notice. Â Â 

 
   
    [4] Â Â  In any event, in the absence of the WCIP, any negligence or inaction 
    by United would not have prevented dual policies on the date of Avantâ€™s accident.Â  
    United did not decide until, at the earliest, August 27, 1997, to add Willowglenâ€™s 
    South Carolina operations to its coverage.Â  At this time the Travelers policy 
    was already in effect.Â  Even if United had given Travelers notice of its policy 
    on August 27, 1997, and Travelers had immediately started cancellation of 
    its policy, the cancellation would not have taken effect until thirty days 
    later.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-406(F)(2) (Supp. 2002) (stating 
    an insurance cancellation shall not be effective until after thirty days from 
    the date of receipt by NCCI of the cancellation notice).
