THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The Housing Authority of the City of Columbia,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Cornerstone Housing, LLC, Cornerstone Columbia,
LLC, and The American 
        Arbitration Association, Inc.,       
Defendants,
Of Whom
Cornerstone Housing, LLC, and Cornerstone Columbia, LLC are,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3677
Heard June 12, 2003 â€“ Filed September 
  15, 2003

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Daniel T. Brailsford, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Thomas M. Kennaday and James C. Gray, Jr. both of Columbia, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

 HOWARD, J.: Â The Columbia Housing 
  Authority (â€œCHAâ€) filed this action seeking to enjoin arbitration of its dispute 
  with Cornerstone Housing and Cornerstone Columbia (collectively, â€œCornerstoneâ€).Â  
  In granting Cornerstoneâ€™s motion to dismiss, the trial court ordered arbitration 
  to proceed.Â  CHA appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On April 6, 1999, Cornerstone and CHA 
  entered an Indefinite Quality/Service Contract (â€œthe first contractâ€) related 
  to the federally funded revitalization of a public-housing project in Columbia 
  known as Celia Saxon Homes.Â  Under the first contract, Cornerstone agreed to 
  perform certain services for CHA.Â  Both parties contracted to use good-faith 
  efforts to agree upon the terms of the Master Development Agreement (â€œthe second 
  contractâ€).Â  The first contract contained an arbitration provision as follows:

16.Â  Resolution of Dispute. Â In the event that there 
  is a bona fide dispute (i.e., a dispute based upon good 
  faith and sincereness, and without deceit or fraud) between CHA and Consultant/Developer, 
  Consultant/Developer shall nevertheless proceed with performance of the services 
  to be provided and the work to be performed under this Contract, or the Task 
  Order in question, pending the resolution of such dispute.Â  In the event that 
  there is a bona fide dispute between CHA and Consultant/Developer 
  in regard to the payment of monies, then those monies which are not in dispute 
  shall nevertheless be paid.Â  This contract is subject to arbitration under S.C. 
  Code ANN 15-48-10, ET SEQ.Â  Both parties may present written evidence to the 
  Arbiter (a duplicate copy of which written evidence shall concurrently therewith 
  be delivered to the other party), and neither party shall consult verbally with 
  the Arbiter without the other party present.

(emphasis as in original). 
On July 27, 2000, CHA and Cornerstone 
  entered into the second contract concerning Celia Saxon Homes.Â  The second contract 
  contained the following arbitration provision:

11.20Â  Dispute Resolution.Â  In the event that there 
  is a bona fide dispute (i.e., a dispute based upon good faith 
  and sincereness, and without deceit or fraud) between The Authority and the 
  Developer, Developer shall nevertheless proceed with performance of the services 
  to be provided and the work to be performed under this Contract, or the Task 
  Order in question, pending the resolution of such dispute.Â  In the event that 
  there is a bona fide dispute between the Authority and the Developer 
  in regard to the payment of monies, then those monies which are not in dispute 
  shall nevertheless be paid.Â  This contract is subject to binding arbitration 
  under the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association.Â  
  Both parties may present written evidence to the arbitrators (a duplicate copy 
  of which written evidence shall concurrently therewith be delivered to the other 
  party), and neither party shall consult verbally with the arbitrators without 
  the other party present.

(emphasis as in original). 
The second contract also contained the 
  following provision related to the United States Department of Housing and Urban 
  Development (â€œHUDâ€):

1.2Â  Role of HUD.Â Â  The parties hereto acknowledge 
  that this Agreement and the closings and the consummation of the transactions 
  contemplated by this Agreement are subject to approval by HUD.Â  The Developer 
  and the Authority agree to cooperate in good faith to obtain all necessary approvals 
  from HUD and acknowledge that approvals from HUD must be obtained as a condition 
  precedent to any obligations contained herein.

(emphasis as in original). 
The second contract was sent to HUD for approval.Â  
  HUD did not approve the contract and required extensive modifications for approval. 
  Â Subsequently, a dispute arose between Cornerstone and CHA resulting 
  in the termination of any further negotiations related to the second contract.Â  
  Based on the arbitration agreements contained in the two contracts, Cornerstone 
  filed an arbitration demand with the American Arbitration Association.Â  CHA 
  countered by filing this lawsuit to enjoin arbitration. Â Cornerstone 
  moved to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), South Carolina Rules 
  of Civil Procedure.Â  Following a hearing, the circuit court granted Cornerstoneâ€™s 
  motion to dismiss the lawsuit.Â  CHA appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA trial judge may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates 
  the plaintiffâ€™s â€˜failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of 
  actionâ€™ in the pleadings filed with the court.â€Â  FOC Lawshe Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. 
  Intâ€™l Paper Co., 352 S.C. 408, 412, 574 S.E.2d 228, 230 (Ct. App. 2002) 
  (quoting Rule 12(b)(6), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure).Â  â€œThe trial 
  court must dispose of a motion for failure to state a cause of action based 
  solely upon the allegations set forth on the face of the complaint.â€ Brown 
  v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d 697, 698 (1987).Â  â€œThe motion 
  cannot be sustained if facts alleged in the complaint and inferences reasonably 
  deducible therefrom would entitle plaintiff to any relief on any theory of the 
  case.â€ Id.Â  â€œAll properly pleaded factual allegations are deemed admitted 
  for the purposes of considering a motion for judgment on the pleadings.â€ Intâ€™l 
  Paper, 352 S.C. at 413, 574 S.E.2d at 230.Â  â€œUpon review, the appellate 
  tribunal applies the same standard of review that was implemented by the trial 
  court.â€Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Agreement 
  to Arbitrate Dispute at Issue
CHA argues the circuit court erred in granting 
  the motion to dismiss and ordering the parties to proceed with arbitration.Â  
  We disagree.
A. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Existence of Arbitration Agreement
â€œThere is a strong presumption in favor of the 
  validity of arbitration agreements because of the strong policy favoring arbitration.â€ 
  Towles v. United HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 37, 524 S.E.2d 839, 844 
  (Ct. App. 1999).
The initial inquiry to be made by the trial court 
  is whether an arbitration agreement exists between the parties. Towles, 
  338 S.C. at 37, 524 S.E.2d at 844-45 (â€œArbitration is available only when the 
  parties involved contractually agree to arbitrate.â€); see Hooters 
  of America v. Phillips, 39 F. Supp. 2d 582, 609 (D.S.C. 1998) (holding issues 
  of â€œsubstantive arbitrabilityâ€ are properly before the trial court and these 
  issues are whether â€œa valid arbitration agreement exists between the parties 
  and . . . [whether] the specific dispute falls within the substantive scope 
  of the agreementâ€ (quoting Glass v. Kidder Peabody & Co., 114 F.3d 
  446, 453 (4th Cir. 1997))).
The determination of whether an arbitration agreement 
  exists is â€œa matter to be forthwith and summarily tried by the Court.â€ [1]  Jackson Mills, Inc. v. BT Capital Corp., 
  312 S.C. 400, 404, 440 S.E.2d 877, 879 (1994) (internal punctuation omitted); 
  see Green Tree Fin. Corp. v. Bazzle, 123 S. Ct. 2402, 2407 (2003) 
  (holding that in the absence of clear and unmistakable evidence to the contrary, 
  â€œcourts assume that the parties intended courts, not arbitrators, to decide 
  . . . certain gateway matters, such as whether the parties have a valid arbitration 
  agreement at allâ€); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(a) (Supp. 2002) 
  (stating if a â€œparty denies the existence of the agreement to arbitrate, the 
  court shall proceed summarily to the determination of the issueâ€ of the existence 
  of the arbitration agreement).
Courts â€œshould apply ordinary state-law 
  principles that govern the formation of contractsâ€ in determining whether an 
  agreement to arbitrate exists. First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan, 
  514 U.S. 938, 944 (1995); Towles, 338 S.C. at 37, 524 S.E.2d at 844 (adopting 
  the reasoning of First Options).
In this case, the parties signed two contracts regarding 
  the revitalization of the public-housing project.Â  Each contract contained an 
  arbitration provision that covered disputes arising between Cornerstone and 
  CHA. See Jaffe v. Gibbons, 290 S.C. 468, 472, 351 S.E.2d 343, 
  345 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œ[W]here both parties have signed a contract, the signing 
  by the first party is in effect his proposal or offer and the signing by the 
  second party is his acceptance thereof; the writing then represents or evidences 
  the bargain between them.â€).Â  The first contract covered the time period from 
  the contractâ€™s signing until the parties entered into the second contract.Â  
  Specifically, the parties agreed to undertake â€œgood-faith negotiations, with 
  the intention of utilizing each otherâ€™s best efforts, to enter into [the second 
  contract].â€Â  The second contract was to come into full force once HUD 
  approved its provisions. 
Under South Carolina law, two contracts 
  executed at different times but which relate to the same subject matter and 
  are entered into by the same parties are to be construed as one contract and 
  considered as a whole. Klutts Resort Realty v. Downâ€™ Round Dev. Corp., 
  268 S.C. 80, 88, 232 S.E.2d 20, 24 (1977).Â  Reading the two contracts in this 
  case together, it is evident the parties agreed that any dispute arising after 
  the signing of the first contract was to be arbitrated. See id.Â  
  Therefore, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that a valid arbitration 
  agreement existed between the parties.Â  See Jackson Mills, 312 
  S.C. at 404, 440 S.E.2d at 879 (holding the determination of whether an arbitration 
  agreement exists is a matter to be summarily tried by the trial court).
B. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Matters Subject to Arbitration
The second issue for the trial court to determine in this 
  case was whether â€œthe specific dispute falls within the substantive scope of 
  the [arbitration] agreement.â€ Phillips, 39 F. Supp. 2d at 609 (holding 
  issues of â€œsubstantive arbitrabilityâ€ are properly before the trial court, including 
  whether a particular dispute is within the scope of the arbitration agreement) 
  (quoting Glass, 114 F.3d at 453)); see Bazzle, 123 S. Ct. 
  at 2407 (holding that in the absence of clear and unmistakable evidence to the 
  contrary, â€œcourts assume that the parties intended courts, not arbitrators, 
  to decide . . . certain gateway matters, such as whether [an arbitration agreement] 
  applies to a certain type of controversyâ€); see also Zabinski v. Bright 
  Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001) (holding the 
  question of â€œwhether the parties have agreed to submit a particular grievance 
  to arbitrationâ€ is an issue for judicial determination but that in making such 
  a decision the â€œcourt is not to rule on the potential merits of the underlying 
  claimsâ€).
â€œTo decide whether an arbitration agreement encompasses a 
  dispute, a court must determine whether the factual allegations underlying the 
  claim are within the scope of the broad arbitration clause.â€ Id. at 597, 
  553 S.E.2d at 118. 
Even when the dispute does not arise under the governing 
  contract, the dispute is subject to arbitration when the contract contains a 
  broadly worded arbitration clause and â€œa â€˜significant relationshipâ€™ exists between 
  the asserted claims and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained.â€Â  
  Id. at 598, 553 S.E.2d at 119 (quoting Long v. Silver, 248 F.3d 
  309, 316 (4th Cir. 2001)).
Assuming, arguendo, there is a gap in the time period 
  explicitly covered by the contracts 
  [2]  containing the arbitration agreements and the disagreement at issue 
  in this case arose during this time period, the dispute is still subject to 
  arbitration. 
First, both contracts contained broadly worded arbitration 
  agreements. The first contract stated, â€œThis contract is subject to arbitration 
  under S.C. Code ANN 15-48-10, ET SEQ.â€ Â The second contract stated, â€œThis 
  contract is subject to binding arbitration under the Commercial Arbitration 
  Rules of the American Arbitration Association.â€ 
Second, the subject matter of each contract centered on the 
  revitalization of the housing project.Â  The first contract focused on negotiations 
  to enter into a second binding contract concerning the revitalization.Â  The 
  second contract contained the specific terms of the revitalization effort that 
  was to be approved by HUD.
Finally, the disagreement concerning continued negotiations 
  between the parties after HUD initially declined to approve the terms of the 
  second contract was significantly related to the subject matter of the first 
  and second contracts.Â  Thus, even if the contracts failed to specifically include 
  the time period when the dispute arose, the dispute at issue is still subject 
  to arbitration. See Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118 
  (â€œ[U]nless the court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause 
  is not susceptible to an interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration 
  should be ordered.â€).
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Lack of 
  Challenge to Arbitration Agreement
CHA argues the first contract was illegal, and 
  thus, unenforceable, and the second contract did not come into legal force.Â  
  Because CHA does not directly challenge the arbitration agreement with either 
  of these arguments, we hold the determination of the merits of these issues 
  is reserved for the arbitrator.
â€œArbitration clauses are separable from the contracts in 
  which they are imbedded.â€ Jackson Mills, 312 S.C. at 403, 440 S.E.2d 
  at 879.Â  â€œ[T]he issue of [the arbitration clauseâ€™s] validity is distinct from 
  the substantive validity of the contract as a whole.â€Â  Munoz v. Green Tree 
  Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 540, 542 S.E.2d 360, 364 (2001) (citing Prima 
  Paint Corp. v. Flood & Conklin Mfg. Co., 388 U.S. 395, 403 (1967)).
â€œ[I]t is only when a party has valid grounds upon which to 
  challenge the arbitration clause itself that arbitration may be avoided.â€ Jackson 
  Mills, 312 S.C. at 403-04, 440 S.E.2d at 879; see South Carolina 
  Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great Western Coal, 312 S.C. 559, 562-63, 437 S.E.2d 
  22, 24 (1993) (holding â€œa party cannot avoid arbitration through rescission 
  of the entire contract when there is no independent challenge to the arbitration 
  clauseâ€).
A. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Illegality of the First Contract
CHA contends the first contract was illegal because Cornerstone 
  was not a licensed contractor under South Carolina Code Annotated section 40-11-370(C) 
  (Supp. 2002). [3] Â  Because CHAâ€™s 
  argument fails to attack the validity of the arbitration agreement itself, we 
  hold the legality of the first contract is an issue for the arbitrator to decide.
Our supreme court addressed a similar argument in Munoz.Â  
  In Munoz, the plaintiff attempted to defeat an arbitration clause in 
  a financing agreement by arguing the South Carolina Consumer Protection Code 
  invalidated the contract and the arbitration clause.Â  In finding the arbitration 
  clause valid, our supreme court stated as follows:

An arbitration clause may be invalidated under a state law 
  only if that law governs the enforceability of all contracts generally.Â  Perry 
  v. Thomas [482 U.S. 483, 492 n.9 (1987)].Â  The Consumer Protection Code 
  does not govern contracts generally but applies only to certain consumer transactions.Â  
  While the requirements of the Consumer Protection Code may be raised on the 
  merits of the contractâ€™s enforceability as a consumer credit transaction, these 
  requirements do not apply to determine the validity of the arbitration clause 
  itself.

343 S.C. at 540, 542 S.E.2d at 364.Â Â  
Similarly, in the present case, section 40-11-370(C) 
  only applies to certain construction contracts and does not govern contracts 
  generally.Â  Thus, the arbitration agreement cannot be invalidated based on the 
  requirements of this statute. Â See Jackson Mills, 312 S.C. at 
  404, 440 S.E.2d at 879 (holding valid grounds to challenge the arbitration agreement 
  itself include claiming â€œthe controversy arose out of events occurring subsequent 
  to expiration of the arbitration agreement itselfâ€ and alleging â€œthe arbitration 
  agreement was never entered intoâ€); see also Zabinski, 346 S.C. 
  at 592, 553 S.E.2d at 116 (â€œ[T]he [Federal Arbitration Act] will preempt any 
  state law that completely invalidates the partiesâ€™ agreement to arbitrate.â€).Â  
  Further, arbitration is the proper place to raise the issue of statutory licensing 
  requirements as a defense to the enforcement of the contract generally. See 
  Bazzle, 123 S. Ct. at 2407 (holding that except for â€œcertain gateway 
  matters, such as whether the parties have a valid arbitration agreement,â€ the 
  parties to an arbitration agreement have agreed that an arbitrator would decide 
  disputes covered by the agreement).
Notwithstanding Munoz, CHA contends Cornerstoneâ€™s 
  violation of the statute made the first contract illegal.Â  However, even if 
  the overall contract is unenforceable, the arbitration provision is not unenforceable 
  unless the reason the overall contract is unenforceable specifically relates 
  to the arbitration provision. See Jackson Mills, 312 S.C. at 403-04, 
  440 S.E.2d at 879 (holding arbitration cannot be avoided when a party opposed 
  to arbitration alleges only a problem with the contract as a whole but not with 
  the arbitration agreement itself).Â  
In this case, CHAâ€™s claim of illegality goes to the contract 
  generally and not the arbitration provision specifically.Â  Because the defense 
  of illegality relates to the contract as a whole, the arbitration provision 
  is still in force and the illegality defense can be considered at the arbitration 
  itself. See Bazzle, 123 S. Ct. at 2407; Phillips, 39 F. 
  Supp. 2d at 609 (holding all issues raised before a trial court not relating 
  to whether â€œa valid arbitration agreement exists between the partiesâ€ or whether 
  â€œthe specific dispute falls within the substantive scope of the agreement . 
  . . fall within the ambit of â€˜procedural arbitrability,â€™ and are within the 
  jurisdiction of the arbitratorâ€ (quoting Glass, 114 F.3d at 453)). 
B. Â Â Â Â  Legal Force of the Second Contract
CHA contends the second contract was never in legal 
  force.Â  Because CHAâ€™s argument does not specifically attack the arbitration 
  agreement, we hold that the enforceability of the second contract is an issue 
  for the arbitrator to determine.
The United States Supreme Court addressed a similar 
  argument in Prima Paint, 388 U.S. at 403-04.Â  In Prima Paint, 
  the party who opposed arbitration alleged it was fraudulently induced to enter 
  into the contract in which the arbitration agreement was located.Â  No independent 
  challenge to the arbitration agreement was made. Â In affirming the trial courtâ€™s 
  decision to dismiss a motion to enjoin arbitration, the Court stated as follows:

[S]ave for the existence of an arbitration clause,Â Â Â Â Â  the 
  . . . court is instructed to order arbitration to proceed once it is satisfied 
  that â€˜the making of the agreement for arbitration or the failure to comply (with 
  the arbitration agreement) is not in issue.â€™Â  Accordingly, if the claim is fraud 
  in the inducement of the arbitration clause itself â€“ an issue which goes to 
  the â€˜makingâ€™ of the agreement to arbitrate â€“ the . . . court may proceed to 
  adjudicate it.Â  But the . . . court [may not] consider claims of fraud in the 
  inducement of the contract generally.

Id. at 403-04 (internal punctuation marks as in original); 
  see Great Western Coal, 312 S.C. at 562-63, 437 S.E.2d at 24 (adopting 
  the reasoning of Prima Paint).
Similarly, CHA argued a problem existed with the second contract 
  but made no independent argument regarding the arbitration agreement.Â  Because 
  the second contract had a provision requiring HUD approval of the contract prior 
  to its provisions having legal effect, CHA argued the contract was not in force.Â  
  However, this argument attacked the second contract without specifically attacking 
  the arbitration agreement. See Jackson Mills, 312 S.C. at 404, 
  440 S.E.2d at 879 (holding valid grounds to challenge the arbitration agreement 
  itself include claiming â€œthe controversy arose out of events occurring subsequent 
  to expiration of the arbitration agreement itselfâ€ and alleging â€œthe arbitration 
  agreement was never entered intoâ€).Â  Further, the language of the HUD-approval 
  clause spoke to the contract generally but did not specifically address the 
  arbitration agreement. 
Thus, CHA cannot avoid arbitration with this argument because 
  it failed to allege an independent challenge to the validity of the arbitration 
  agreement. See id. at 403-04, 440 S.E.2d at 879 (holding when 
  a party opposed to arbitration alleges only a problem with the contract as a 
  whole but not with the arbitration agreement itself then arbitration cannot 
  be avoided); see Phillips, 39 F. Supp. 2d at 609 (holding all 
  issues raised before a trial court not relating to whether â€œa valid arbitration 
  agreement exists between the partiesâ€ or whether â€œthe specific dispute falls 
  within the substantive scope of the agreement . . . fall within the ambit of 
  â€˜procedural arbitrability,â€™ and are within the jurisdiction of the arbitratorâ€ 
  (quoting Glass, 114 F.3d at 453)).
Further, since the failure to obtain HUD approval of the 
  second contract is a defense to the contract generally and not to the arbitration 
  agreement specifically, arbitration is the proper place to raise the defense. 
  See Bazzle, 123 S. Ct. at 2407 (holding that except for â€œcertain 
  gateway matters, such as whether the parties have a valid arbitration agreement,â€ 
  the parties to an arbitration agreement have agreed that an arbitrator would 
  decide disputes covered by the agreement).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing reasons, the decision of 
  the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and JEFFERSON, Acting Judges, 
  concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Neither party asserts the arbitration clause contained â€œclear and 
    unmistakable evidenceâ€ that the parties agreed to have an arbitrator decide 
    the threshold issue of whether an arbitration agreement existed between the 
    parties. First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan, 514 U.S. 938, 944 
    (1995) (â€œCourts should not assume that the parties agreed to arbitrate arbitrability 
    unless there is â€˜clea[r] and unmistakabl[e]â€™ evidence that they did so.â€ (quoting 
    AT&T Tech. v. Communications Workers of America, 475 U.S. 643, 
    649 (1986))).Â  Further, a review of the language in both the first and second 
    contracts does not reveal language indicating clear and convincing evidence 
    that the parties intended for an arbitrator to decide the threshold issue 
    of whether a valid arbitration agreement existed. See Merrill Lynch, 
    Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. v. Havird, 335 S.C. 642, 646, 518 S.E.2d 
    48, 50 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding clear evidence exists when the language of 
    the agreement between the parties â€œclearly evinces an intent for the arbitratorâ€ 
    to decide threshold issues).Â  Thus, the issue was properly before the circuit 
    court.

 
   
    [2]  Arguably, the time between the parties entering into the second contract 
    and that contract coming into full effect was not covered by either contract.

 
   
    [3]  â€œAn entity which does not have a valid license as required by this 
    chapter [relating to licensed contractors] may not bring an action either 
    at law or in equity to enforce the provisions of a contract. An entity that 
    enters into a contract to engage in construction in a name other than the 
    name that appears on its license may not bring an action either at law or 
    in equity to enforce the provisions of the contract.â€ Section 40-11-370(C).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gay Ellen Coon,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
James Moore Coon,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
H.E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 3678
Heard April 9, 2003 â€“ Filed September 
  22, 2003

REVERSED AND REMANDED

Ronald L. Richter, Jr., of Charleston, for Appellant.
Alex B. Cash, of Charleston, for Respondent.

 HOWARD, J.:Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  This is an action by Gay Ellen Coon (Wifeâ€) to enforce the payment of retirement 
  benefits previously ordered by the family court.Â  James Moore Coon (â€œHusbandâ€) 
  moved pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, to 
  vacate the previously entered final order.Â  Husband asserted the family court 
  lacked subject matter jurisdiction to order payment of more than fifty percent 
  of his disposable military retirement pay to his spouse because to do so violated 
  the Uniformed Services Former Spouseâ€™s Protection Act (â€œUSFSPAâ€), 10 U.S.C.A. 
  Â§ 1408 (1998).Â  The family court agreed and vacated the prior order.Â  Wife appeals.Â  
  We reverse and reinstate the family courtâ€™s prior order.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In July 1999, the family court approved a settlement 
  agreement between Husband and Wife, acknowledging the Husbandâ€™s military retirement 
  account was a marital asset subject to division.Â  In accordance with the agreement, 
  the order provided that Wife was entitled to one-hundred percent of the proceeds 
  of Husbandâ€™s military retirement account for nine years, and following the nine-year 
  period, â€œthe plan administrator will be directed to divided the proceeds equally 
  between the parties.â€Â  
No Qualified Domestic Relations Order (â€œQDROâ€) 
  was sent to or approved by the Secretary of Defense in accordance with the USFSPA. 
  Â Instead, Husband deposited the full amount of his retirement pay into 
  a jointly held bank account, and Wife used the funds.Â  
As a result, Husband was deemed the recipient of 
  the funds and was responsible for the taxes.Â  He did not withhold the proper 
  amount of taxes in 1999 and part of 2000, so he withheld additional taxes in 
  2000 to cover out-of-pocket expenses he had incurred the previous year. 
Wife then filed this enforcement action, arguing 
  Husband violated the final order of July 1999 by increasing the amount of withholding 
  deducted from the retirement benefit.Â  Husband responded by filing a motion 
  to vacate the original order approving the agreement pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), 
  arguing the order Wife sought to enforce was void for lack of subject matter 
  jurisdiction because it allocated more than fifty percent of his disposable 
  military retirement pay in violation of the USFSPA. Â The family court 
  heard Husbandâ€™s Rule 60(b)(4) motion and held Wifeâ€™s rule to show cause in abeyance.Â  
  The family court concluded:

The provisions of the [USFSPA] limit[] this Courtâ€™s jurisdiction 
  as to military retirement pay to a total amount not to exceed fifty percent 
  of the disposable retired pay.Â  For this reason, any order of the Court which 
  attempts to allocate any sum in excess of the said fifty percent is void for 
  lack of this Courtâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  

(emphasis added).
On April 2, 2001, the family court sent its order 
  to the clerk of court and to the partiesâ€™ attorneys.Â  Wife served her motion 
  to reconsider on Husband on April 6, 2001, and on the clerk of court on April 
  9, 2001. Â However, she waited until she received a â€œclockedâ€ copy of 
  her motion from the clerk of court, in August 2001, before she served her motion 
  on the presiding judge. Â On October 3, 2001, the family court issued 
  an order reaffirming its ruling.Â  In its order, the family court also indicated 
  Wifeâ€™s motion to reconsider was untimely because she did not provide the presiding 
  judge with a copy of the motion within ten days of filing.Â  Wife served and 
  filed her notice of appeal to this Court on November 1, 2001.Â  This appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Timeliness of Appeal
Initially, Husband asserts Wifeâ€™s appeal to this 
  Court is untimely because she failed to comply with the requirements of Rule 
  59(g), South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Husband contends because Wife 
  failed to serve a copy of her motion to reconsider on the family court within 
  ten days of filing it with the clerk of court, the time for her appeal to this 
  Court has expired.Â  We disagree with Husbandâ€™s reading of Rule 59(g) and find 
  Wifeâ€™s appeal to be timely.
Rule 59(g) requires â€œa party filing a written motion 
  under this rule [to] provide a copy of the motion to the judge within ten (10) 
  days after the filing of the motion.â€Â  The notes to Rule 59 state the 1998 amendment 
  adding subsection (g) was â€œintended to help insure that the judge is promptly 
  notified that the motion has been filed.â€ (emphasis added).Â  As this 
  Court discussed in Gallagher v. Evert, â€œ[t]here is no indication that 
  the failure to transmit a copy of the motion to the circuit court affects the 
  tolling provision of Rule 203(b)(1), South Carolina Appellate Court Rules. [1] Â  Therefore, the time for filing the notice of appeal did not 
  begin to run until after the circuit court denied the motion.â€ 353 S.C. 59, 
  63, 577 S.E.2d 217, 219 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In accordance with Rule 59(g) and 
  this Courtâ€™s decision in Gallagher, we hold Wife was not required to 
  file her notice of appeal until after the family court issued its order denying 
  her motion to reconsider.Â  Thus, her appeal to this Court is timely.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  USFSPA & Jurisdiction
Wife contends the family court erred by vacating 
  its prior order.Â  Wife asserts the family court had subject matter jurisdiction 
  because the retirement account is marital property.Â  We agree and hold the limitation 
  on the percentage of retirement benefits the family court is permitted to allocate 
  speaks to the family courtâ€™s authority and not its subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  Thus, we reinstate the family courtâ€™s prior order.
A.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Definition of Void
Initially, we note the posture of this case.Â  Husband 
  brought this motion pursuant to Rule 60(b)(4), South Carolina Rules of Civil 
  Procedure, asserting the family courtâ€™s prior final order approving the parties 
  agreement was void for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Thus, our 
  inquiry is limited solely to determining the family courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction 
  in this matter.
â€œA void judgment is one that, from its inception, 
  is a complete nullity and is without legal effect and must be distinguished 
  from one which is merely â€˜voidable.â€™â€Â  Thomas & Howard Co. v. T.W. Graham 
  and Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995) (quoting 46 Am. Jur.2d 
  Judgments Â§ 31 (1994)).Â  â€œThe definition of void under the rule . . . encompasses 
  . . .Â  judgments from courts which lacked subject matter jurisdiction.â€Â  McDaniel 
  v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. 
  App. 1996) (internal quotations omitted); see also Ross v. Richland 
  County, 270 S.C. 100, 103, 240 S.E.2d 649, 650 (1978) (holding that if â€œâ€˜a 
  court is without jurisdiction of the subject matter, any action with respect 
  to such a cause, other than to dismiss it, is absolutely voidâ€™â€ (quoting Fox 
  v. Board of Regents of Univ. of Mich., 134 N.W.2d 146, 148 (Mich. 1965))).
However, irregularities which do not involve jurisdiction 
  do not render a judgment void.Â  Thomas & Howard Co., 318 S.C. at 
  291, 457 S.E.2d at 343.

[Furthermore,] [t]here is a wide difference between a want 
  of jurisdiction in which case the court has no power to adjudicate at all, and 
  a mistake in the exercise of undoubted jurisdiction in which case the action 
  of the trial court is not void although it may be subject to direct attack on 
  appeal.Â  A judgment will not be vacated for a mere irregularity which does 
  not affect the justice of the case, and of which the party could have availed 
  himself, but did not do so until judgment was rendered against him.

Id. (emphasis added) (internal citations 
  omitted).Â  Moreover, when a court acts with proper subject matter jurisdiction 
  but takes some action outside of its authority, the party against whom the act 
  is done must object and directly appeal.Â  See Cosgrove v. Butler, 
  1 S.C. 241, 243 (1869) (â€œIf such departures be not excepted to, the Court may 
  consider objection to them as waived.Â  And it may be asserted, as a general 
  rule, that where there is no want of jurisdiction . . . , [the Courtâ€™s] judgment 
  will be binding, even although affected by irregularity which would have defeated 
  the proceeding if objection had been timely and properly made.â€ (emphasis added)).Â  
  Thus, if the family court had jurisdiction over the military retirement account, 
  its original order is not void.
B.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Jurisdiction v. Authority
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction refers to the courtâ€™s 
  â€˜power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings 
  in question belong.â€™â€Â  Watson v. Watson, 319 S.C. 92, 93, 460 S.E.2d 
  394, 395 (1995) (quoting Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 237-38, 
  442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994)).Â  South Carolina Code Annotated section 20-7-420(2) 
  (Supp. 2003) grants the family court the exclusive jurisdiction â€œ[t]o hear and 
  determine actions: [f]or divorce a vinculo matrimonii . . . and in other marital 
  litigation between the parties, and for settlement of all legal and equitable 
  rights of the parties in the actions in and to the real and personal property 
  of the marriage.â€ (emphasis added); cf. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 
  (Supp. 2003) (stating the family court does not have jurisdiction to apportion 
  nonmarital property).
In this case, the disputed property is a military 
  retirement account, and we are required to examine the federal authority creating 
  the property to determine its status.Â  The USFSPA specifically permits state 
  courts â€œ[s]ubject to the limitations of this section, . . . [to] treat 
  disposable retired pay . . . either as property solely of the member or as property 
  of the member and his spouse in accordance with the law of the jurisdiction 
  of such court.â€Â  10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408(c)(1) (1998) (emphasis added).Â  Clearly, Congress 
  has chosen to permit the states to determine independently whether to treat 
  military retirement benefits as marital property.
Thus, we must turn to the applicable South Carolina 
  authority to determine the status of a military retirement account in this State.Â  
  In Tiffault v. Tiffault, our supreme court held military retirement benefits 
  â€œconstitute an earned property right which, if accrued during the marriage, 
  is subject to equitable distribution.â€ 303 S.C. 391, 392-93, 401 S.E.2d 157, 
  158 (1991).Â  Therefore, pursuant to Congressâ€™ invitation, our state has determined 
  military retirement accounts are marital property.Â  However, were the law as 
  settled as this concise statement from our supreme court might indicate, the 
  current inquiry would not likely be before us.
Notwithstanding the holding in Tiffault, 
  Husband argues the family courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction is limited by 
  the 1990 amendment to 10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408(e)(1) (1998) [2] .Â  A brief review of the history 
  of the USFSPA is necessary to an understanding of this issue.Â  
In McCarthy v. McCarthy, the United States 
  Supreme Court ruled that the states had no authority to order the equitable 
  distribution of military retirement benefits. 453 U.S. 210, 223 (1981).Â  In 
  direct response to McCarthy, the USFSPA was enacted, and from its inception 
  limited the percentage of disposable military retirement pay that could be allotted 
  to a non-military spouse.Â  The initial language restricted the amount the government 
  administrator could pay to a non-military spouse to fifty percent.Â  In construing 
  this language, some states applied the fifty-percent limitation only to direct 
  payments from the administrator but not to the aggregate amount that could be 
  awarded to the non-military spouse.Â  See, e.g., Grier v. Grier, 
  731 S.W.2d 931, 932-33 (Tex. 1987) (holding the USFSPA did not limit the amount 
  of retirement benefits that could be apportioned under Texas community property 
  law but did limit the percentage of the military retirement benefit that was 
  subject to direct payment); Deliduka v. Deliduka, 347 N.W.2d 52, 55 (Minn. 
  Ct. App. 1984) (holding â€œa state court wishing to award a former spouse more 
  than fifty percent of disposable retired pay must order direct government payments 
  and payments by the member of the military to the spouseâ€). 
To address the various state court interpretations 
  of the fifty-percent restriction, the 1990 amendment changed the restriction 
  to apply to all court-ordered divisions of disposable military retirement pay 
  pertaining to former spouses. 10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408(e)(1) (1998).Â  The 1990 amendment 
  to the Act changed the manner in which the payment was restricted.Â  After the 
  1990 amendment, the fifty-percent restriction on payment of disposable military 
  retirement pay was reworded to apply to divisions of retirement benefits made 
  under any court order pertaining to former spouses. See H.R. Rep. No. 
  101-665, at 3004-05 (1990). 
The 1990 House Report stated that the amendment 
  to subsection (e)(1) â€œreflect[ed] a public policy judgment on the appropriate 
  role of the federal government in limiting state court jurisdiction in 
  divorce cases involving military retired pay [and] is consistent with the balancing 
  of state and federal interests that has been the hallmark of this law since 
  its inception.â€Â  H.R. Rep. No. 101-665, at 3005 (emphasis supplied by Husband).Â  
  The report addressed the amendmentâ€™s language by explaining that the provision 
  stating â€œthe aggregate amount of retired pay that would be payable to [former 
  spouses] would not exceed fifty percent of the service memberâ€™s disposable retired 
  payâ€ applied both when a court orders the government administrator to pay the 
  amount directly to the non-military spouse and when the amount is paid indirectly 
  to the non-military spouse through the retired spouse. H.R. Rep. No. 101-665, 
  at 3006; see In re MacMeeken, 117 B.R. 642, 644-45 (Bankr. D. 
  Kan. 1990) (indicating the pre-1990 subsection (e)(1) failed to clearly express 
  that a non-military spouse should never be awarded more than fifty percent of 
  the retired spouseâ€™s disposable military retirement pay, but rather, it appeared 
  Congress intended for the fifty percent limit to apply solely to awards 
  paid directly by the benefits administrator to the non-military spouse).Â  
Based upon this report, Husband argues the limitation 
  is jurisdictional, and therefore, the order was void.Â  Cf. Bowen v. 
  Bowen, 327 S.C. 561, 566, 490 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding once 
  the family court determined property was not marital property, the family court 
  had no jurisdiction to address the propertyâ€™s ownership or â€œdeal with [the property] 
  in any wayâ€).Â  We disagree with Husbandâ€™s reading of the 1990 amendment to subsection 
  (e)(1).
It is generally recognized that the presumption 
  of concurrent federal and state jurisdiction over cases involving federal law 
  â€œcan be rebutted by an explicit statutory directive, by unmistakable implication 
  from legislative history, or by a clear incompatibility between state-court 
  jurisdiction and federal interests.â€ Gulf Offshore Co. v. Mobil Oil Corp., 
  453 U.S. 473, 478 (1981); see Hairston v. Travelers Cas. & Sur. 
  Co., 232 F.3d 1348, 1349-50 (11th Cir. 2000) (quoting Gulf Offshore); 
  Resolution Trust Corp. v. Foust, 869 P.2d 183, 188 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1993) 
  (adopting the reasoning of Gulf Offshore).Â  However, there is nothing 
  in the language of the Act, the amendment, or the legislative history indicating 
  an intention to preempt state court subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Having reviewed 
  the entire House Report and in light of the history of the statute, we conclude 
  the portion of the legislative history to which Husband refers does not evince 
  an â€œunmistakable implicationâ€ to limit a stateâ€™s court subject matter jurisdiction 
  with respect to allocating more than fifty percent of a spouseâ€™s disposable 
  military retirement pay. Gulf Offshore, 453 U.S. at 478.Â  In light of 
  its context and usage, we conclude the use of the term â€œjurisdictionâ€ in the 
  report refers to this stateâ€™s authority to award more than fifty percent of 
  a spouseâ€™s disposable military retirement pay.Â  
The USFSPAâ€™s savings clause further undermines 
  any argument that Congress explicitly directed that the fifty-percent limitation 
  is jurisdictional, thereby preempting traditional state rules regarding finality 
  of judgments.Â  The savings clause states: â€œA court order which itself . . . 
  provides for the payment of an amount which exceeds the amount of disposable 
  retired pay available for payment because of the limit set forth in [subsection 
  (e)(1)] . . . shall not be considered to be irregular on its face solely for 
  that reason.â€Â  10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408(e)(5) (1998).Â  Congress anticipated state courts 
  would issue orders awarding more than fifty percent of the disposable military 
  retirement pay.Â  However, in light of this prospect, Congress chose not to explicitly 
  state that these orders would be void for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  Instead, this subsection purports to â€œsaveâ€ these orders by indicating they 
  should not be deemed irregular.
We have found no reported case in this or any other 
  jurisdiction ruling that when a court awards more than fifty percent of a spouseâ€™s 
  disposable military retirement pay that court lacks subject matter jurisdiction.Â  
  Instead, the cases addressing this issue have held that an award of more than 
  fifty percent of disposable military retirement pay is subject to direct attack 
  on appeal and is reversible error.Â  See, e.g., In re Marriage of Bowman, 
  972 S.W.2d 635, 637-39 (Mo. Ct. App. 1998) (reversing, on direct appeal, 
  an award of more than fifty percent of a spouseâ€™s disposable military pay because 
  it violated section 1408(e)(1), reasoning â€œâ€˜the USFSPA permits a state court 
  to consider the gross value of retirement benefits in computing the value 
  of the marital estate.Â  However, the USFSPA prohibits a state court from awarding 
  the non-military spouse the right to collect more than fifty percent of the 
  net monthly retirement payment.â€™â€) (quoting Beesley v. Beesley, 
  758 P.2d 695, 699 (Idaho 1988)) (emphasis in Beesley)).Â  
Although we have found no rulings directly on point, 
  this Courtâ€™s decision concerning military disability pay under the provisions 
  of the USFSPA is instructive. See Price v. Price, 325 S.C. 379, 
  480 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In Price, the family court approved a 
  settlement agreement in which the husband agreed to pay to his wife a certain 
  amount of his total military retirement benefits, which included his disability 
  pay â€“ an item not considered to be disposable military retirement pay under 
  the USFSPA.Â  325 S.C. at 380, 480 S.E.2d at 92.Â  Subsequently, the husband unilaterally 
  reduced his payments to his wife because he had waived an additional amount 
  of his retirement pay in favor of disability pay.Â  The wife sought to compel 
  the husband to make monthly payments according to the settlement agreement. 
  Id. at 381, 480 S.E.2d at 92-93.Â  Relying on Mansell v. Mansell, 
  husband sought a reduction in the payments to his wife.Â  490 U.S. 581, 589-95 
  (1989) (holding the USFSPA does not give state courts the authority to treat 
  total military retirement benefits as property subject to equitable distribution).Â  
  The family court granted the wifeâ€™s motion to compel and this Court affirmed.Â  

Although this Court acknowledged federal authority 
  limiting the family courtâ€™s consideration of disability benefits as marital 
  property subject to equitable distribution, this Court held husband should not 
  be permitted to complain the family court erred in enforcing the terms of the 
  agreement he willingly entered into with his wife. Price, 325 S.C. at 
  383, 480 S.E.2d at 94.Â  Notably, this Court concluded the federal limitation 
  did not divest the family court of subject matter jurisdiction. Id.Â  
  Thus, this Court affirmed the settlement agreement.Â  See McLellan 
  v. McLellan, 533 S.E.2d 635, 637-39 (Va. Ct. App. 2000) (affirming the denial 
  of the husbandâ€™s motion to vacate a prior court order because it approved a 
  settlement agreement awarding the wife a portion of the husbandâ€™s military disability 
  pay in violation of section 1408); Forney v. Minard, 849 P.2d 724, 729 
  (Wyo. 1993) (refusing to vacate the trial courtâ€™s order awarding wife one-hundred 
  percent of her husbandâ€™s military retirement pay even though the trial court 
  ordered the benefits administrator to pay wife directly, finding the USFSPAâ€™s 
  limitations do not restrict state jurisdiction to only fifty percent of the 
  disposable retirement pay).Â  
For the foregoing reasons, we conclude the family 
  court erred in vacating its prior order for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
CONCLUSION
The family courtâ€™s order vacating its prior order 
  is REVERSED, and the original family court order approving the settlement 
  agreement, which awarded Wife one-hundred percent of the proceeds of Husbandâ€™s 
  military retirement account for a nine-year period, is reinstated.Â  We remand 
  for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, J., and STROM, Acting Judge, 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  Rule 203(b)(1) provides: â€œWhen a timely . . . motion to alter or 
    amend the judgment . . . has been made, the time for appeal for all parties 
    shall be stayed and shall run from receipt of written notice of entry of the 
    order granting or denying such motion.â€

 
   
     
    [2]    The amendment states â€œ[t]he total amount of the disposable retired 
    pay of a member payable under all court orders pursuant to subsection (c) 
    may not exceed fifty percent of such disposable retired pay.â€ 10 U.S.C. Â§ 
    1408(e)(1) (1998).Â  Subsection (c) is entitled, â€œAuthority for [state] court 
    to treat retired pay as property of the member and spouse.â€ 10 U.S.C. Â§ 1408(c) 
    (1998).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The Vestry and Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross,       
        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Orkin Exterminating Company, Inc., Terminix Service Company, Inc., Terminix 
        International, Inc. d/b/a Terminix of Delaware Corporation, Cuttino Builders, 
        Inc. and Henry D. Boykin, A.I.A., architect,       
Defendants,
of whom Orkin Exterminating Company, Inc. and Terminix Service Company, 
        Inc. and Terminix International, Inc., d/b/a Terminix of Delaware Corporation 
        are the        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
L. Henry McKellar, Circuit Court Judge

Published Opinion 3679
Heard June 10, 2003 â€“ Filed September 
  22, 2003Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED in Part and REVERSED in 
  Part


  
    
      
Clinch H. Belser, Jr., of Columbia; 
  for Appellant Terminix Service Co.;
J. Rutledge Young, III and Tom 
  Wills, of Charleston; R. Wade Marionneaux and Voris E. Johnson, Jr., of Atlanta; 
  all for Appellant Orkin Exterminating, Co.
Thomas S. Tisdale, Stephen Brown, and Stephen P. Groves, of 
  Charleston; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Orkin Exterminating Company 
  and Terminix Service Company both appeal from the trial courtâ€™s order denying 
  their motions to compel arbitration.Â  We affirm with respect to Orkin and reverse 
  with respect Terminix.
FACTS
This case arises from a lawsuit filed 
  by the Church of the Holy Cross after it discovered termite damage within the 
  church building. [1] Â  In 1975, the church contracted 
  with Terminix for the installation of a termite protection system within the 
  church building.Â  To this end, Terminix drilled holes through the churchâ€™s interior 
  concrete floor and installed pipes into which pesticide could be injected.Â  
  This contract did not contain an arbitration clause. In June 2000, after the 
  church discovered termite damage, the church entered into a new contract with 
  Terminix for a baiting system to be used outside of the church building.Â  This 
  2000 contract contained an arbitration clause.Â  
From 1976 until 1985, the church contracted with 
  Orkin for the inspection and treatment of termites within the church building. 
  [2] Â  When treating for termites, Orkin utilized the system installed by 
  Terminix.Â  Orkin terminated this service contract in 1985, after the church 
  inadvertently failed to make two annual payments.Â  In 1987, the church entered 
  into a new contract with Orkin for the continued inspection and treatment of 
  the church building.Â  This contract also did not contain an arbitration clause.Â  
  In 1998, the Church and Orkin entered into a separate contract for the inspection 
  and treatment of the parish hall. 
  [3] Â  This contract contained an arbitration clause; however, it did not 
  incorporate or reference the 1987 contract for Orkinâ€™s treatment of the church 
  building.Â Â Â  
After termites were discovered 
  in the church building, the church sued both Orkin and Terminix for damages. 
   [4] Â  Orkin and Terminix each 
  filed a motion to compel arbitration.Â  Orkin argued that the arbitration clause 
  in its 1998 contract with the church is broad enough to compel arbitration of 
  disputes arising from the prior contracts.Â  Terminix raised the same argument 
  with respect to its 2000 contract with the church.Â  
The trial court denied both 
  Orkinâ€™s and Terminixâ€™s motions to compel arbitration.Â  The trial court held 
  there was nothing in the 1998 Orkin contract or the 2000 Terminix contract signifying 
  a retroactive effect.Â  Thus, the trial court held arbitration was not required 
  for causes of action arising out of the prior contracts.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Whether a claim is subject to 
  arbitration is an issue for judicial determination, unless the parties have 
  agreed otherwise.Â  Stokes v. Metro. Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609, 
  571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œDeterminations of arbitrability are subject 
  to de novo review.â€Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In South Carolina, the test for 
  determining whether a particular issue is subject to arbitration is articulated 
  in Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001).Â  
  â€œThe policy of the United States and South Carolina is to favor arbitration 
  of disputes.â€Â  Id. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â Â  â€œArbitration rests on 
  the agreement of the parties, and the range of issues that can be arbitrated 
  is restricted by the terms of the agreement.â€ Id. at 596-97, 553 S.E.2d 
  at 118.Â  â€œArbitration is a matter of contract, and a party cannot be required 
  to submit to arbitration any dispute which he has not agreed to submit.â€Â  Id. 
  at 597, 553 S.E.2d 118.Â  To decide whether an arbitration agreement covers a 
  particular dispute, the court must determine whether the factual allegations 
  underlying the claim fall within the scope of the agreement, irrespective of 
  the label given to the cause of action.Â  Id.Â  When interpreting arbitration 
  agreements within the scope of the FAA, 
  [5]  due regard must be given to the federal policy in favor of arbitration, 
  and any ambiguity in the scope of the arbitration clause must be resolved in 
  favor of arbitration.Â  Stokes, 351 S.C. at 512, 571 S.E.2d at 714.Â  â€œ[U]nless 
  the court can say with positive assurance that arbitration clause is not susceptible 
  to an interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should be ordered.â€Â  
  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  See also Towles 
  v. United HealthCare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 41-42, 524 S.E.2d 839, 846 (Ct. 
  App. 1999) (stating a motion to compel arbitration should be denied only where 
  the arbitration clause is not susceptible of any interpretation that would cover 
  the asserted claim).
The issue before this court is 
  whether the churchâ€™s claims against Orkin and Terminix fall within the scope 
  of each partyâ€™s arbitration clause.Â  In this case, the claims asserted by the 
  church arose prior to the execution of the contracts which contain the arbitration 
  clause.Â  It is therefore necessary for this court to determine whether the arbitration 
  clauses in Orkinâ€™s and Terminixâ€™s contracts were sufficiently broad so as to 
  embrace disputes arising under prior contracts.Â  Because this issue has received 
  little discussion in South Carolina, we look to the federal courts for instruction 
  as to the scope of the clauses at issue in this case.Â  It is necessary to understand 
  fully the scope of the clauses in order to effectively determine whether either 
  is capable of an interpretation which covers the claims asserted by the church.
Courts have retroactively applied 
  arbitration clauses to disputes arising under prior contracts, but in doing 
  so, the courts have generally found the existence of a broadly worded clause 
  which governed the overall relationship between the parties. 
  [6] Â  See, e.g., Caraâ€™s Notions, Inc. v. Hallmark Cards, Inc., 
  140 F.3d 566, 568-71 (4th Cir. 1998) (finding a broad arbitration clause which 
  called for arbitration of â€œ[a]ny controversy or claim arising out of or relating 
  to . . . any aspects of the relationshipâ€ established that the clause was intended 
  to apply to all conflicts between the parties and not only to conflicts arising 
  under the specific contract containing the arbitration clause); Zink v. Merrill 
  Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, Inc., 13 F.3d 330, 331-33 (10th Cir. 1993) 
  (holding the parties were required to submit their claims to arbitration where 
  the dispute predated the execution of the arbitration clause because the clause 
  provided for the arbitration of â€œany controversy . . . arising out of your business 
  or this agreementâ€); Rand Bond of N. Am., Inc. v. Saul Stone & Co., 
  726 F. Supp. 684, 687-88 (N.D. Ill. 1989) (finding arbitrable a dispute arising 
  prior to the execution of the arbitration agreement where the arbitration clause 
  provided that the agreement extended to â€œ[a]ny controversy or claim arising 
  out of or relating to your accountsâ€); B.G. Balmer & Co. v. United States 
  Fid. & Guar. Co., 1998 WL 764669 (E.D. Pa. 1998) (noting that where 
  an arbitration clause speaks in terms of relationships and not timing, it applies 
  to disputes even if the claim arose before the agreement was executed).Â  The 
  common theme underlying these cases is that the parties expressly agreed that 
  all controversies between them, not just those appurtenant to the contract 
  containing the clause, were to be submitted to arbitration.Â  That being the 
  case, the source of the claim or injury is not dispositive, for the parties 
  have manifested an intention to arbitrate all of their disputes arising from 
  their business relations, not just those arising under a particular contract.Â  

Where the language of the arbitration clause is 
  not as broad, courts have refused to mandate the arbitration of disputes unrelated 
  to the contract containing the clause.Â  In Sec. Watch, Inc. v. Sentinel Sys. 
  Inc., 176 F.3d 369, 372 (6th Cir. 1999), the court found that a clause requiring 
  arbitration of â€œâ€˜all disputes, controversies, or claims . . . arising out of 
  or relating to the Products furnished pursuant to this Agreement or acts or 
  omissions of Distributor or AT & T under this Agreement . . . â€ could not 
  be used to compel arbitration of disputes relating to products shipped under 
  prior agreements.Â  The court noted that while the scope of the clause was very 
  broad and would govern all disputes involving the contract in which it was contained, 
  it did not extend over time to affect disputes arising out of prior contracts.Â Â  
  Id.
In In re Hops Antitrust Litig., 655 F. Supp. 
  169, 172-73 (E.D. Mo. 1987), the court considered whether an arbitration agreement 
  applied to disputes arising out of transactions related to separate agreements 
  previously executed between the parties.Â  The plaintiff asserted claims against 
  the defendant arising out of numerous purchase agreements for the sale of hops.Â  
  Later contracts between the parties contained an arbitration clause stating 
  that â€œâ€˜any dispute arising out of or relating to this agreement, including its 
  interpretation, validity, scope and enforceability, shall be resolved exclusively 
  and finally by arbitration . . . .â€™â€ Id. at 170.Â  The court held this 
  language did not compel arbitration of disputes arising under prior contracts, 
  finding each contract to be a separate and discreet transaction between the 
  parties for the sale and purchase of hops.Â  Id. at 172.Â Â  The court stated: 
  â€œThe record reflects no agreement by the parties to amend earlier contracts 
  to provide for arbitration of disputes [arising under those contracts] . . . 
  .â€Â  Id. at 173.Â  
We derive from these cases that 
  the mere fact that an arbitration clause might apply to matters beyond the express 
  scope of the underlying contract does not alone imply that the clause should 
  apply to every dispute between the parties.Â  For example, a clause compelling 
  arbitration for any claim â€œarising out of or relating to this agreementâ€ may 
  cover disputes outside the agreement, but only if those disputes relate to the 
  subject matter of that agreement.Â  See Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 598, 
  553 S.E.2d at119 (â€œA broadly-wordedÂ  arbitration clause applies to disputes 
  that do not arise under the governing contract when a â€˜significant relationshipâ€™ 
  exists between the asserted claims and the contract in which the arbitration 
  clause is contained.â€).Â  On the other hand, if the clause contains language 
  compelling arbitration of any dispute arising out of the relationship of the 
  parties, it does not matter whether the particular claim relates to the contract 
  containing the clause; it matters only that the claim concerns the relationship 
  of the parties.Â  See, e.g., Caraâ€™s Notions, 140 F.3d at 568-71.Â  
  Under Zabisnki, such a clause would have the broadest scope because it 
  could be interpreted to apply to every dispute between the parties.
A.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Orkinâ€™s 
  appeal
The pertinent language in the arbitration 
  provision of the 1998 Orkin contract is as follows:Â  

ANY DISPUTE ARISING OUT OF OR RELATING TO THIS AGREEMENT 
  OR THE SERVICES PERFORMED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT OR TORT BASED CLAIMS FOR PERSONAL 
  OR BODILY INJURY OR DAMAGE TO REAL OR PERSONAL PROPERTY SHALL BE FINALLY RESOLVED 
  BY ARBITRATION ADMINISTERED UNDER THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION RULES OF THE AMERICAN 
  ARBITRATION ASSOCIATION. 

Orkin argues the arbitration clause 
  applies to claims for damage to real property, and thus applies to this dispute 
  as a result of the churchâ€™s allegation of damages to the church building.Â  We 
  disagree.
We do not construe Orkinâ€™s arbitration 
  clause so broadly as to encompass any and all disputes arising out of the relationship 
  of the parties.Â  See, e.g.,Â  Caraâ€™s Notions, 140 F.3d at 568-71; 
  Zink, 13 F.3d at 331-33; Rand Bond, 726 F. Supp. at 687-88.Â  Rather, 
  we interpret this clause as applying only to disputes arising out of or relating 
  to the agreement in which it is contained.Â  Accordingly, if arbitration is to 
  be compelled, it must be found that â€œa â€˜significant relationshipâ€™ exists between 
  the [churchâ€™s] claims and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained.â€Â  
  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 598, 553 S.E.2d at119.
At the time the church and Orkin 
  entered into the 1998 contract, the church had not yet discovered the termite 
  damage, which forms the basis of its claims.Â  Accordingly, the church could 
  not have intended to submit to arbitration specific claims for which it had 
  no knowledge, unless the church intended to arbitrate every claim of this nature.Â  
  We recognize the broad policy in favor of arbitration; however, we do not broadly 
  construe Orkinâ€™s arbitration clause as applying to every incident of property 
  damage, irrespective of the time in which the claim arose or the property upon 
  which the damage was suffered.Â  Even assuming, arguendo, that the clause 
  may be construed to apply to property which is not the subject of the 1998 contract, 
  the words chosen by Orkin in no way evince an intention to apply the clause 
  to claims which had accrued at a time prior to the execution of the 1998 contract.Â  
  Although the arbitration clause does not expressly limit its application to 
  the parish hall, it contains no language expanding its application to other 
  properties either.Â  As was noted in Hendrick v. Brown & Root, Inc., 
  50 F.Supp. 2d 527, 535 (E.D.Va. 1999): 

[T]he supreme court has never held that an intent to arbitrate 
  can be found from the absence of contractual language evincing an intent to 
  arbitrate a particular kind of dispute.Â  Rather, the court has held that only 
  doubtful interpretations of contractual language respecting the scope of the 
  agreement to arbitrate certain kinds of disputes are to be resolved in favor 
  of arbitration.Â  To convert that principal into a rule that a [party] may insulate 
  itself from pre-existing claims by failing to say so in explicit terms is a 
  fundamental distortion of the principle. 

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no 
  correlation between the factual allegations underlying the churchâ€™s complaint 
  and the subject matter of the 1998 contract, and thus we hold the churchâ€™s claims 
  do not fall within the scope of Orkinâ€™s arbitration clause.Â  The terms chosen 
  by Orkin to define the scope of its arbitration agreement are wholly ineffective 
  to broaden its application to pre-existing claims involving unrelated real property.Â  
  Accordingly, we hold the trial judge properly denied Orkinâ€™s motion to compel 
  arbitration. 
B.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Terminixâ€™s 
  appeal
Terminix argues that, because the 
  arbitration clause in the 2000 contract required arbitration for all disputes 
  between the parties, the trial court erred in denying its motion to compel arbitration.Â Â  

The pertinent 
  language in the arbitration provision in the 2000 Terminix contract is as follows:Â  


The [Church] and Terminix agree that all matters in dispute 
  between them, including but not limited to (i) any controversy or claim between 
  them arising out of or relating to this Agreement, (ii) any wood destroying 
  insect report with respect to the described property or (iii) the described 
  property in any way, in any such case whether by virtue of contract, tort or 
  otherwise, shall be settled exclusively by arbitration.Â  

Applying Zabinski, we look 
  to the factual allegations of the churchâ€™s claim against Terminix to determine 
  whether there is a substantial relationship of the allegations to the subject 
  matter of the 2000 contract.Â  The church contends that there is no relation 
  between the dispute and the 2000 contract because the dispute concerns defective 
  services to the inside of the church building while the 2000 contract was for 
  the installation of a termite baiting system in the ground on the outside of 
  the church building.Â  We are not persuaded by this distinction.Â  Whether the 
  treatment was to the inside of the building or to the earth outside the building, 
  the common purpose was the prevention of termite infestations in the building 
  structure.Â  At the hearing on the motion to compel arbitration, counsel for 
  the church stated the purpose of the 2000 contract was as follows:

[T]he church called Terminix in the year 2000 and said we 
  have got a grand problem out here.Â  Weâ€™ve got termites that have eaten up the 
  church.Â  We need to get them stopped.Â  So Terminix comes out, enters a separate 
  contract[] . . . to [install] these bait stations . . . .Â Â  And that was solely 
  for the purpose of mitigating the damage that had been by the termites coming 
  in, inside the church. 

It is clear from these statements 
  that the 2000 contract was executed as a direct result of the damage caused 
  by Terminixâ€™s alleged failure to perform under its prior contract.Â  Therefore, 
  we find the churchâ€™s current allegations against Terminix substantially relate 
  to the subject matter of the 2000 contract considering the 2000 contract concerns 
  the treatment (albeit by different methods) of the same building in an effort 
  to mitigate the very damages complained of in the present dispute.Â  The church 
  was aware of the termite damage (and thus the existence of a cause of action 
  against Terminix) at the time the church executed the contract containing the 
  arbitration clause.Â  In light of the purpose for which the 2000 contract was 
  entered, we cannot find that the claims at issue in this case were not within 
  the partiesâ€™ contemplation at the time the contract was executed.Â  Moreover, 
  the express terms of the clause provide that â€œall matters in dispute 
  between [the parties] . . . shall be settled exclusively by arbitration.â€Â  This 
  language is very broad, and it is more akin to the language generally held to 
  reflect an intention to apply to matters arising out of the relationship of 
  the parties.Â  The fact that the dispute accrued prior to the execution of the 
  2000 contract is not dispositive where, as here, the terms of the agreement 
  are susceptible to an interpretation which covers any dispute existing between 
  the parties.Â  See Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118 
  (stating that where the clause is capable of an interpretation that covers the 
  dispute, arbitration should be ordered); Towles, 338 S.C. at 41-42, 524 
  S.E.2d at 846 (stating a motion to compel arbitration should be denied only 
  where the arbitration clause is not susceptible to any interpretation that would 
  cover the asserted claim).Â  Because we conclude the arbitration clause is susceptible 
  to an interpretation which brings within its broad scope the claims asserted 
  by the church, we are constrained to find the trial court erred in denying Terminixâ€™s 
  motion to compel arbitration of those claims. 
CONCLUSION
Because 
  the scope of Orkinâ€™s 1998 arbitration clause does not encompass the churchâ€™s 
  claims, which arose under prior, unrelated contracts, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s 
  denial of Orkinâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.Â Â Â  Terminixâ€™s arbitration agreement 
  is much broader, however, and we hold its clause is susceptible to an interpretation 
  that covers the claims asserted by the church.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the 
  trial courtâ€™s decision to deny Terminixâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.
AFFIRMED in Part and REVERSED 
  in Part.
CONNOR and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  There are two buildings on the Church property:Â  the church building 
    and a separate parish hall.Â  

 
   
    [2]  None of the parties can locate a copy of this first contract between 
    the Church and Orkin, although its existence is not contested.Â  

 
   
    [3] Â  The parish hall is referred to as the â€œparsonageâ€ in the 1998 Orkin 
    contract.

 
   
    [4]  The Church also filed suit against both the architect and the contractor 
    responsible for the restoration of the church building.Â  However, the circuit 
    court granted these defendantsâ€™ motions to compel arbitration, and they are 
    not involved in this appeal.Â  

 
   [5]  The applicability of the Federal Arbitration Act, 
    9 U.S.C. Â§1 et. seq., is not in dispute.

 
   
    [6] Â  An arbitration provision will also cover disputes arising under 
    prior contracts where the clause contains retroactive, time-specific language 
    mandating its application to previously executed contracts.Â  See Merrill 
    Lynch, Pierce, Fenner, & Smith, Inc. v. Kirton, 719 So.2d 201, 203 
    (Ala. 1998) (holding an â€œarbitration agreement expressly extended to all controversies 
    relating to the partiesâ€™ transactions and agreements, â€˜whether entered into 
    prior [to], on, or subsequent to the date hereofâ€™ clearly indicated that disputes 
    related to prior transactions were to be arbitratedâ€).Â  Here, neither contract 
    contains retroactive language.
