THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Robert L. Townsend, Respondent,
v.
Patricia Joyce Townsend, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
Jamie Lee Murdock, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3680Â Â Â 
Heard August 20, 2003 â€“ Filed September 
  29, 2003 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Flo Lester Vinson, of Florence, for Appellant.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Robert L. Widener, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This is an appeal from an 
  order of the family court granting the respondent Robert L. Townsendâ€™s request 
  for a reduction in child support.Â  Patricia Joyce Townsend, Townsendâ€™s former 
  wife and custodial parent of the children affected by the family courtâ€™s order, 
  appeals that reduction.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
The parties, who were married on March 
  12, 1993, have three children, one of whom is autistic.Â  At the time of the 
  divorce hearing on June 29, 2000, the children were six, five, and three years 
  old.Â  The father is a medical doctor while the mother is a full-time homemaker.Â  
  The father earned $250,000 a year or about $21,000 a month at the time of the 
  divorce hearing.Â  
A settlement agreement filed on July 5, 
  2000, set the amount of monthly child support at $3,250.Â  When the parties entered 
  into the agreement on June 29, 2000, the father had submitted his resignation 
  to his employer, Dillon Internal Medicine, some thirty days or so before.Â  The 
  agreement was based on the fatherâ€™s â€œincome as of that moment,â€ that is, the 
  date of the settlement agreement. 
  [1] Â  The family court approved the settlement agreement, incorporating 
  it into its order of divorce.Â  
As anticipated, the father left Dillon 
  International Medicine in November 2000, four months after the family court 
  filed its order on July 5, 2000.Â  He opened his own medical practice on December 
  1, 2000, employing twelve employees.Â  Approximately two weeks after he opened 
  his medical practice, the father sought a reduction in his child support obligation.
Following the divorce, the father remarried, paid 
  counsel fees to adopt his new wifeâ€™s son, and bought a house that carries a 
  mortgage of $185,000.Â  In addition to his new home, the father owns a rental 
  house.Â  He also has five automobiles, including a Durango that he helped his 
  new wife purchase after borrowing $27,000, and three collector Corvettes that 
  cost him $915 a month.Â  During the first five months of 2001, the fatherâ€™s current 
  wife, using â€œmarital funds,â€ took â€œa coupleâ€ of vacations â€œfor a couple of weeks 
  at a time.â€Â  The father also paid to fly his current wife, his mother, and his 
  mother-in-law to and from Michigan for family visits. 
The fatherâ€™s notarized, handwritten March 6, 2001 
  financial declaration places his gross salary and wages at $15,000 a month and 
  shows him receiving an additional $550 a month in rental income.Â  In other words, 
  he earns approximately $186,000 a year.Â  
The family court reduced the fatherâ€™s child support 
  obligation by $895 a month, requiring him to make monthly payments of $2,355.Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
While the court of appeals may 
  make findings of fact based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence 
  when reviewing a family court order [2] , questions concerning child support 
  are ordinarily committed to the discretion of the family court, whose conclusions 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing of an abuse of discretion. [3] Â  An abuse of discretion occurs either when 
  the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon 
  findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support. [4] Â  
A substantial or material change of circumstances 
  must occur to warrant a modification of child support. 
  [5] Â  Generally, a change in future circumstances within the contemplation 
  of the parties at the time of a child support award affords no basis for a modification 
  of the award [6] , unless the future change is 
  one that cannot be addressed at the time because of other considerations. [7] Â  Moreover, a reduction in the earning capacity 
  of a supporting parent does not necessarily require a reduction in child support. [8] Â  Indeed, a reduction in child support cannot be based on a 
  decrease in the noncustodial parentâ€™s income absent a strong showing by the 
  latter that he or she can no longer make the support payments required by the 
  earlier order. [9] Â  Where the amount of child support is based 
  on a settlement agreement, the party requesting a modification has an even heavier 
  burden. [10] Â  
ISSUE
Whether the family court erred in finding 
  there had been a substantial or material change in circumstances to warrant 
  a decrease in child support. [11] 
  
ANALYSIS
In our view, the father failed to make 
  the strong showing necessary for a downward modification of his child support 
  obligation for his three children.Â  First, the father continues to maintain 
  a high standard of living, notwithstanding his change of jobs.Â  He has acquired 
  a new home, helped his new wife to buy a new motor vehicle, paid for his new 
  wifeâ€™s vacations, paid for other trips for her and other family members, and 
  made payments for three collector Corvettes each month in an amount that exceeds 
  by $20 the amount of the child support reduction granted him by the family court. 
  [12] Â Â Â  Second, while we recognize the fatherâ€™s earnings have decreased 
  since he left Dillon Internal Medicine to open his own medical practice, as 
  he planned to do before the divorce, nothing in the record persuades us that 
  his earning potential has been adversely affected by the move. 
  [13] Â  His current gross income as reflected in his financial statement 
  is still quite substantial and of an amount sufficient for him to honor the 
  agreement to pay the sum of $3,250 a month in child support, an agreement the 
  family court incorporated into its order.
Finally, the supreme courtâ€™s decision in Sharps [14]  does not aid the father.Â  Aside from the 
  fact that the case deals with alimony and not child support (which receives 
  closer court scrutiny than does alimony), here the obligation had been set a 
  mere six months before, not thirteen years before, as in Sharps.Â  The 
  latter case also has no application where the events that brought about the 
  change were put in motion prior to the entry of a settlement agreement.
 REVERSED.
BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  
    The father acknowledged that when he negotiated the partiesâ€™ agreement, he 
    contemplated that his change in employment could result in a decrease in income.Â  
    The father stated he specifically considered several alternative methods of 
    calculating his income, but expressly agreed to an amount based on his current 
    income, notwithstanding the fact that he would be leaving his employment with 
    Dillon Internal Medicine and going out on his own.

 
   [2] Â  
    Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 477 S.E.2d 727 (Ct. App. 1996).

 
    [3] Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 320 
    S.E.2d 706 (1984).

 
   [4] Â  McKnight v. McKnight, 
    283 S.C. 540, 324 S.E.2d 91 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  

 
   [5] Â  
    Calvert v. Calvert, 287 S.C. 130, 336 S.E.2d 884 (Ct. App. 1985).

 
    [6] Â  Id. at 139, 336 S.E.2d at 889.

 
   [7] Â  
    Sharps v. Sharps, 342 S.C. 71, 535 S.E.2d 913 (2000).Â  

 
   [8] Â  
    Vestal v. Vestal, 297 S.C. 215, 375 S.E.2d 355 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  

 
   [9] Â  
    Miller v. Miller, 299 S.C. 307, 384 S.E.2d 715 (1989); see generally 
    Garris v. Cook, 278 S.C. 622, 300 S.E.2d 483 (1983) (holding that the 
    party seeking to modify a support obligation has the burden of proving a sufficient 
    change of circumstances).Â  

 
   [10]  Ratchford v. Ratchford, 
    295 S.C. 297, 368 S.E.2d 214 (Ct. App. 1988); 27 C.J.S. Divorce Â§ 735, 
    at 386 (1986).Â  

 
   [11]  
    The father attempts to couch an unappealed adverse evidentiary ruling by the 
    family court as an â€œadditional sustaining ground.â€Â  Cf. Iâ€™On, L.L.C. 
    v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) 
    (The supreme court â€œchose to avoid using the term â€˜additional sustaining groundâ€™ 
    in the present appellate court rules.Â  Instead, the present rules provide 
    simply that â€˜[r]espondentâ€™s brief may also contain argument asking the court 
    to affirm for any ground appearing on the record as provided by Rule 220(c), 
    [SCACR].â€) (alterations in original).Â  The ruling excluded certain evidence 
    on the question of whether he voluntarily left his employment with Dillon 
    Internal Medicine.Â  The family court viewed the question of whether the father 
    voluntarily left that medical practice as an issue resolved by the court-approved 
    settlement agreement.Â  We agree with the family court.Â  See 27 C.J.S. 
    Divorce Â§ 735, at 387 (1986) (stating that evidence dealing with matters 
    occurring before the entry of the original decree will usually be excluded).Â  
  

 
   [12]  
    See Kielar v. Kielar, 311 S.C. 466, 429 S.E.2d 851 (Ct. App. 
    1993) (ruling that there was no material change in circumstances warranting 
    modification of alimony or child support where an anesthesiologist earning 
    in excess of $300,000 a year at the time of the divorce later took a job paying 
    $180,000); see also Eagerton v. Eagerton, 265 S.C. 90, 95, 217 
    S.E.2d 146, 148 (1975) (ruling that a modification of child support payments 
    was not warranted because of a change in the fatherâ€™s health and financial 
    ability where his income dropped from approximately $200,000 annually to $100,000 
    annually, stating that the father â€œwas a man of sufficient property and means 
    to meet the ordered payments if minded to do soâ€).

 
   [13]  
    See Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina Substantive 
    Law 591 (2001) (â€œThe primary factors to be considered under the guidelines 
    are the actual gross incomes and earning potential of both parties.â€).

 
   [14]  
    342 S.C. 71, 535 S.E.2d 913 (2000).
